quoteText: The mater will be delighted to see you again   after all those years,
subQuotationList: ['The mater will be delighted to see you again   after all those years,']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Your mother keeps well?
subQuotationList: ['Your mother keeps well?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh, yes. I suppose you know that she has married again?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes. I suppose you know that she has married again?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Rotten little bounder too! I can tell you,
Hastings, it's making life jolly difficult for us. As for Evie   you
remember Evie?
subQuotationList: ['Rotten little bounder too!', "I can tell you,\nHastings, it's making life jolly difficult for us. As for Evie   you\nremember Evie?"]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Inglethorp']], [['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Evelyn Howard']]]

quoteText: No.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, I suppose she was after your time. She's the mater's factotum,
companion, Jack of all trades! A great sport   old Evie! Not precisely
young and beautiful, but as game as they make them.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I suppose she was after your time. She's the mater's factotum,\ncompanion, Jack of all trades! A great sport   old Evie! Not precisely\nyoung and beautiful, but as game as they make them."]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionTextsList: [['she', 'your', 'She', "the mater's factotum,\ncompanion, Jack of all trades", 'A great sport', 'old Evie']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard']]]

quoteText: You were going to say      ?
subQuotationList: ['You were going to say      ?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a
second cousin or something of Evie's, though she didn't seem
particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an
absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He's got a great black beard,
and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned
to him at once, took him on as secretary   you know how she's always
running a hundred societies?
subQuotationList:
["Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a
second cousin or something of Evie's, though she didn't seem
particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an
absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He's got a great black beard,
and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned
to him at once, took him on as secretary   you know how she's always
running a hundred societies?"]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionTextsList: [['this fellow', 'He', "a\nsecond cousin or something of Evie's", 'Evie', 'she', 'The fellow', 'He', 'the mater', 'him', 'him', 'you', 'she']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Evie'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
Well, of course the war has turned the hundreds into thousands. No
doubt the fellow was very useful to her. But you could have knocked us
all down with a feather when, three months ago, she suddenly announced
that she and Alfred were engaged! The fellow must be at least twenty
years younger than she is! It's simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but
there you are   she is her own mistress, and she's married him.
subQuotationList:
["Well, of course the war has turned the hundreds into thousands. No
doubt the fellow was very useful to her. But you could have knocked us

years younger than she is! It's simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but
there you are   she is her own mistress, and she's married him."]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: It must be a difficult situation for you all.
subQuotationList: ['It must be a difficult situation for you all.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Difficult! It's damnable!
subQuotationList: ["Difficult! It's damnable!"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Got a drop or two of petrol still, you see, Mainly
owing to the mater's activities.
subQuotationList: ['Got a drop or two of petrol still, you see,', "Mainly\nowing to the mater's activities."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: I'm afraid you'll find it very quiet down here, Hastings.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid you'll find it very quiet down here, Hastings."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: My dear fellow, that's just what I want.
subQuotationList: ["My dear fellow, that's just what I want."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, it's pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill
with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife
works regularly    on the land'. She is up at five every morning to milk,
and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It's a jolly good life taking
it all round   if it weren't for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!
subQuotationList:
["Oh, it's pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill
with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife
works regularly    on the land'. She is up at five every morning to milk,
and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It's a jolly good life taking
it all round   if it weren't for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
I wonder if we've
time to pick up Cynthia. No, she'll have started from the hospital by
now.
subQuotationList: ["I wonder if we've\ntime to pick up Cynthia. No, she'll have started from the hospital by\nnow."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Cynthia! That's not your wife?
subQuotationList: ["Cynthia! That's not your wife?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, Cynthia is a prot  g  e of my mother's, the daughter of an old
schoolfellow of hers, who married a rascally solicitor. He came a
cropper, and the girl was left an orphan and penniless. My mother came
to the rescue, and Cynthia has been with us nearly two years now. She
works in the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster, seven miles away.
subQuotationList:
["No, Cynthia is a prot  g  e of my mother's, the daughter of an old
schoolfellow of hers, who married a rascally solicitor. He came a
cropper, and the girl was left an orphan and penniless. My mother came
to the rescue, and Cynthia has been with us nearly two years now. She
works in the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster, seven miles away."]
speaker: John Cavendish

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Murdoch'], ['Miss Murdoch'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Miss Murdoch'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Miss Murdoch'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish'], ['Miss Murdoch']]]

quoteText: Hullo, Evie, here's our wounded hero! Mr. Hastings   Miss Howard.
subQuotationList: ["Hullo, Evie, here's our wounded hero! Mr. Hastings   Miss Howard."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Weeds grow like house afire. Can't keep even with 'em. Shall press you
in. Better be careful.
subQuotationList: ["Weeds grow like house afire. Can't keep even with 'em. Shall press you\nin. Better be careful."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: I'm sure I shall be only too delighted to make myself useful,
subQuotationList: ["I'm sure I shall be only too delighted to make myself useful,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Don't say it. Never does. Wish you hadn't later.
subQuotationList: ["Don't say it. Never does. Wish you hadn't later."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
You're a cynic, Evie, Where's tea to-day   inside
or out?
subQuotationList: ["You're a cynic, Evie,", "Where's tea to-day   inside\nor out?"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Out. Too fine a day to be cooped up in the house.
subQuotationList: ['Out. Too fine a day to be cooped up in the house.']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Come on then, you've done enough gardening for to-day.
subQuotationList: ["Come on then, you've done enough gardening for to-day."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: you know. Come and be refreshed.
subQuotationList: ['you know. Come and be refreshed.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Well, I'm
inclined to agree with you.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', "I'm\ninclined to agree with you."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: My wife, Hastings,
subQuotationList: ['My wife, Hastings,']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Then you'll write to the Princess after tea, Alfred? I'll write to
Lady Tadminster for the second day, myself. Or shall we wait until we
hear from the Princess? In case of a refusal, Lady Tadminster might
open it the first day, and Mrs. Crosbie the second. Then there's the
Duchess   about the school f  te.
subQuotationList:
["Then you'll write to the Princess after tea, Alfred? I'll write to
Lady Tadminster for the second day, myself. Or shall we wait until we
hear from the Princess? In case of a refusal, Lady Tadminster might
open it the first day, and Mrs. Crosbie the second. Then there's the
Duchess   about the school f  te."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
Yes, certainly. After tea will do quite well. You are so thoughtful,
Alfred dear.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, certainly. After tea will do quite well. You are so thoughtful,\nAlfred dear.']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText:
Why, if it isn't too delightful to see you again, Mr. Hastings, after
all these years. Alfred, darling, Mr. Hastings   my husband.
subQuotationList: ["Why, if it isn't too delightful to see you again, Mr. Hastings, after\nall these years. Alfred, darling, Mr. Hastings   my husband."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
This is a pleasure, Mr. Hastings. Emily
dearest, I think that cushion is a little damp.
subQuotationList: ['This is a pleasure, Mr. Hastings.', 'Emily\ndearest, I think that cushion is a little damp.']
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp
referringExpression: He placed a wooden hand in mine and said

quoteText: Is soldiering your regular profession, Mr. Hastings?
subQuotationList: ['Is soldiering your regular profession, Mr. Hastings?']
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

quoteText: No, before the war I was in Lloyd's.
subQuotationList: ["No, before the war I was in Lloyd's."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: And you will return there after it is over?
subQuotationList: ['And you will return there after it is over?']
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

quoteText: Perhaps. Either that or a fresh start altogether.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps. Either that or a fresh start altogether.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
What would you really choose as a profession, if you could just
consult your inclination?
subQuotationList: ['What would you really choose as a profession, if you could just\nconsult your inclination?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Well, that depends.
subQuotationList: ['Well, that depends.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No secret hobby? Tell me   you're drawn to something?
Everyone is   usually something absurd.
subQuotationList: ['No secret hobby?', "Tell me   you're drawn to something?\nEveryone is   usually something absurd."]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: You'll laugh at me.
subQuotationList: ["You'll laugh at me."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Well, I've always had a secret hankering to be a detective!
subQuotationList: ["Well, I've always had a secret hankering to be a detective!"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: The real thing   Scotland Yard? Or Sherlock Holmes?
subQuotationList: ['The real thing   Scotland Yard? Or Sherlock Holmes?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Oh, Sherlock Holmes by all means. But really, seriously, I am awfully
drawn to it. I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous
detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvellous little fellow.
He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of
method. My system is based on his   though of course I have progressed
rather further. He was a funny little man, a great dandy, but
wonderfully clever.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, Sherlock Holmes by all means. But really, seriously, I am awfully
drawn to it. I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous
detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvellous little fellow.
He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of
method. My system is based on his   though of course I have progressed

speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionTextsList: [['a man', 'a very famous\ndetective', 'he', 'He', 'a marvellous little fellow', 'He', 'his', 'He', 'a funny little man, a great dandy']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText:
Like a good detective story myself, Lots of
nonsense written, though. Criminal discovered in last chapter. Everyone
dumbfounded. Real crime   you'd know at once.
subQuotationList: ['Like a good detective story myself,', "Lots of\nnonsense written, though. Criminal discovered in last chapter. Everyone\ndumbfounded. Real crime   you'd know at once."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: There have been a great number of undiscovered crimes,
subQuotationList: ['There have been a great number of undiscovered crimes,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Don't mean the police, but the people that are right in it. The
family. You couldn't really hoodwink them. They'd know.
subQuotationList: ["Don't mean the police, but the people that are right in it. The\nfamily. You couldn't really hoodwink them. They'd know."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
Then, you think that if you were mixed up in a
crime, say a murder, you'd be able to spot the murderer right off?
subQuotationList: ['Then,', "you think that if you were mixed up in a\ncrime, say a murder, you'd be able to spot the murderer right off?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Of course I should. Mightn't be able to prove it to a pack of lawyers.
But I'm certain I'd know. I'd feel it in my fingertips if he came near
me.
subQuotationList: ["Of course I should. Mightn't be able to prove it to a pack of lawyers.\nBut I'm certain I'd know. I'd feel it in my fingertips if he came near\nme."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: It might be a    she',
subQuotationList: ["It might be a    she',"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Might. But murder's a violent crime. Associate it more with a man.
subQuotationList: ["Might. But murder's a violent crime. Associate it more with a man."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Not in a case of poisoning.
subQuotationList: ['Not in a case of poisoning.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Dr. Bauerstein was saying yesterday that, owing to the general
ignorance of the more uncommon poisons among the medical profession,
there were probably countless cases of poisoning quite unsuspected.
subQuotationList: ['Dr. Bauerstein was saying yesterday that, owing to the general\nignorance of the more uncommon poisons among the medical profession,\nthere were probably countless cases of poisoning quite unsuspected.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Why, Mary, what a gruesome conversation! It
makes me feel as if a goose were walking over my grave. Oh, there's
Cynthia!
subQuotationList: ['Why, Mary, what a gruesome conversation!', "It\nmakes me feel as if a goose were walking over my grave. Oh, there's\nCynthia!"]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Why, Cynthia, you are late to-day. This is Mr. Hastings   Miss Murdoch.
subQuotationList: ['Why, Cynthia, you are late to-day. This is Mr. Hastings   Miss Murdoch.']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Sit down here on the grass, do. It's ever so much nicer.
subQuotationList: ["Sit down here on the grass, do. It's ever so much nicer."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Alfred Inglethorp']

quoteText: You work at Tadminster, don't you, Miss Murdoch?
subQuotationList: ["You work at Tadminster, don't you, Miss Murdoch?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard']

quoteText: For my sins.
subQuotationList: ['For my sins.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Alfred Inglethorp']

quoteText: Do they bully you, then?
subQuotationList: ['Do they bully you, then?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard']

quoteText: I should like to see them!
subQuotationList: ['I should like to see them!']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Alfred Inglethorp']

quoteText:
I have got a cousin who is nursing, And she is terrified
of    Sisters'.
subQuotationList: ['I have got a cousin who is nursing,', "And she is terrified\nof    Sisters'."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard']

quoteText:
I don't wonder. Sisters _are_, you know, Mr. Hastings. They simp-ly
_are_! You've no idea! But I'm not a nurse, thank heaven, I work in the
dispensary.
subQuotationList: ["I don't wonder. Sisters _are_, you know, Mr. Hastings. They simp-ly\n_are_! You've no idea! But I'm not a nurse, thank heaven, I work in the\ndispensary."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Alfred Inglethorp']

quoteText: How many people do you poison?
subQuotationList: ['How many people do you poison?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard']

quoteText: Oh, hundreds!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, hundreds!']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Alfred Inglethorp']

quoteText:
Cynthia, do you think you could write a few
notes for me?
subQuotationList: ['Cynthia,', 'do you think you could write a few\nnotes for me?']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Certainly, Aunt Emily.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, Aunt Emily.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Alfred Inglethorp']

quoteText:
John will show you your room. Supper is at half-past seven. We have
given up late dinner for some time now. Lady Tadminster, our Member's
wife   she was the late Lord Abbotsbury's daughter   does the same. She
agrees with me that one must set an example of economy. We are quite a
war household; nothing is wasted here   every scrap of waste paper, even,
is saved and sent away in sacks.
subQuotationList:
["John will show you your room. Supper is at half-past seven. We have
given up late dinner for some time now. Lady Tadminster, our Member's

agrees with me that one must set an example of economy. We are quite a

is saved and sent away in sacks."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Cynthia
subQuotationList: ['Cynthia']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText:
Look here, Mary, there's the deuce of a mess. Evie's had a row with
Alfred Inglethorp, and she's off.
subQuotationList: ["Look here, Mary, there's the deuce of a mess. Evie's had a row with\nAlfred Inglethorp, and she's off."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Evie? Off?
subQuotationList: ['Evie? Off?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Yes; you see she went to the mater, and   Oh,   here's Evie herself.
subQuotationList: ["Yes; you see she went to the mater, and   Oh,   here's Evie herself."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: At any rate, I've spoken my mind!
subQuotationList: ['At any rate,', "I've spoken my mind!"]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: My dear Evelyn, this can't be true!
subQuotationList: ['My dear Evelyn,', "this can't be true!"]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
True enough! Afraid I said some things to Emily she won't forget or
forgive in a hurry. Don't mind if they've only sunk in a bit. Probably
water off a duck's back, though. I said right out:
subQuotationList: ["True enough! Afraid I said some things to Emily she won't forget or\nforgive in a hurry. Don't mind if they've only sunk in a bit. Probably\nwater off a duck's back, though. I said right out:"]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: She was very angry. Natural! I went on,
subQuotationList: ['She was very angry. Natural! I went on,']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: What did she say?
subQuotationList: ['What did she say?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: to accuse her
subQuotationList: ['to accuse her']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
The sooner I left
her house the better. So I'm off.
subQuotationList: ["The sooner I left\nher house the better. So I'm off."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: But not now?
subQuotationList: ['But not now?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: This minute!
subQuotationList: ['This minute!']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Mr. Hastings, you're honest. I can trust you?
subQuotationList: ["Mr. Hastings, you're honest. I can trust you?"]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
Look after her, Mr. Hastings. My poor Emily. They're a lot of
sharks   all of them. Oh, I know what I'm talking about. There isn't one
of them that's not hard up and trying to get money out of her. I've
protected her as much as I could. Now I'm out of the way, they'll
impose upon her.
subQuotationList:
["Look after her, Mr. Hastings. My poor Emily. They're a lot of
sharks   all of them. Oh, I know what I'm talking about. There isn't one
of them that's not hard up and trying to get money out of her. I've
protected her as much as I could. Now I'm out of the way, they'll
impose upon her."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
Of course, Miss Howard, I'll do everything I can, but I'm
sure you're excited and overwrought.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, Miss Howard,', "I'll do everything I can, but I'm\nsure you're excited and overwrought."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Young man, trust me. I've lived in the world rather longer than you
have. All I ask you is to keep your eyes open. You'll see what I mean.
subQuotationList: ["Young man, trust me. I've lived in the world rather longer than you\nhave. All I ask you is to keep your eyes open. You'll see what I mean."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Above all, Mr. Hastings, watch that devil   her husband!
subQuotationList: ['Above all, Mr. Hastings, watch that devil   her husband!']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Who is that?
subQuotationList: ['Who is that?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: That's Dr. Bauerstein,
subQuotationList: ["That's Dr. Bauerstein,"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: And who is Dr. Bauerstein?
subQuotationList: ['And who is Dr. Bauerstein?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
He's staying in the village doing a rest cure, after a bad nervous
breakdown. He's a London specialist; a very clever man   one of the
greatest living experts on poisons, I believe.
subQuotationList: ["He's staying in the village doing a rest cure, after a bad nervous\nbreakdown. He's a London specialist; a very clever man   one of the\ngreatest living experts on poisons, I believe."]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionTextsList: [['He', 'He', 'a London specialist', 'a very clever man', 'one of the\ngreatest living experts on poisons']]

quoteText: And he's a great friend of Mary's,
subQuotationList: ["And he's a great friend of Mary's,"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
Come for a stroll, Hastings. This has been a most rotten business. She
always had a rough tongue, but there is no stauncher friend in England
than Evelyn Howard.
subQuotationList: ['Come for a stroll, Hastings. This has been a most rotten business. She\nalways had a rough tongue, but there is no stauncher friend in England\nthan Evelyn Howard.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: That's a pretty girl,
subQuotationList: ["That's a pretty girl,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: That is Mrs. Raikes.
subQuotationList: ['That is Mrs. Raikes.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: The one that Miss Howard
subQuotationList: ['The one that Miss Howard']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Exactly,
subQuotationList: ['Exactly,']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Styles is really a glorious old place,
subQuotationList: ['Styles is really a glorious old place,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Yes, it's a fine property. It'll be mine some day   should be mine now
by rights, if my father had only made a decent will. And then I
shouldn't be so damned hard up as I am now.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, it's a fine property. It'll be mine some day   should be mine now\nby rights, if my father had only made a decent will. And then I\nshouldn't be so damned hard up as I am now."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Hard up, are you?
subQuotationList: ['Hard up, are you?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
My dear Hastings, I don't mind telling you that I'm at my wits' end
for money.
subQuotationList: ["My dear Hastings, I don't mind telling you that I'm at my wits' end\nfor money."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Couldn't your brother help you?
subQuotationList: ["Couldn't your brother help you?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Lawrence? He's gone through every penny he ever had, publishing rotten
verses in fancy bindings. No, we're an impecunious lot. My mother's
always been awfully good to us, I must say. That is, up to now. Since
her marriage, of course
subQuotationList:
["Lawrence? He's gone through every penny he ever had, publishing rotten
verses in fancy bindings. No, we're an impecunious lot. My mother's
always been awfully good to us, I must say. That is, up to now. Since
her marriage, of course"]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
Such a charming invitation from Mrs. Rolleston. Lady Tadminster's
sister, you know. The Rollestons came over with the Conqueror   one of
our oldest families.
subQuotationList: ["Such a charming invitation from Mrs. Rolleston. Lady Tadminster's\nsister, you know. The Rollestons came over with the Conqueror   one of\nour oldest families."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: What a lot of bottles! Do you really know what's in them all?
subQuotationList: ['What a lot of bottles!', "Do you really know what's in them all?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Say something original, Every single person who
comes up here says that. We are really thinking of bestowing a prize on
the first individual who does _not_ say: And I
know the next thing you're going to say is:    How many people have you
poisoned?
subQuotationList:
['Say something original,', 'Every single person who
comes up here says that. We are really thinking of bestowing a prize on
the first individual who does _not_ say:', "And I
know the next thing you're going to say is:    How many people have you
poisoned?"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
If you people only knew how fatally easy it is to poison someone by
mistake, you wouldn't joke about it. Come on, let's have tea. We've got
all sorts of secret stores in that cupboard. No, Lawrence   that's the
poison cupboard. The big cupboard   that's right.
subQuotationList:
["If you people only knew how fatally easy it is to poison someone by
mistake, you wouldn't joke about it. Come on, let's have tea. We've got
all sorts of secret stores in that cupboard. No, Lawrence   that's the
poison cupboard. The big cupboard   that's right."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Nibs'], ['Miss Murdoch', 'Nibs'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText: Come in,
subQuotationList: ['Come in,']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: _I_'m not really here to-day.
subQuotationList: ["_I_'m not really here to-day."]
speaker: Nibs
addressees: ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings', 'A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse']
referringExpression: Nibs who waved her towards Cynthia with the somewhat enigmatical remark

quoteText: This should have been sent up this morning.
subQuotationList: ['This should have been sent up this morning.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Nibs', 'A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse']

quoteText: Sister is very sorry. She forgot.
subQuotationList: ['Sister is very sorry. She forgot.']
speaker: A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse

quoteText: Sister should read the rules outside the door.
subQuotationList: ['Sister should read the rules outside the door.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Nibs', 'A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse']

quoteText: So now it can't be done until to-morrow,
subQuotationList: ["So now it can't be done until to-morrow,"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Nibs', 'A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse']

quoteText: Don't you think you could possibly let us have it to-night?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you think you could possibly let us have it to-night?"]
speaker: A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Murdoch'], ['Miss Murdoch'], ['A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse']]]

quoteText:
Well, we are very busy, but if we have time
it shall be done.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'we are very busy, but if we have time\nit shall be done.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
addressees: ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Nibs', 'A Young And Rather Scared Looking Nurse']

quoteText: Discipline must be maintained?
subQuotationList: ['Discipline must be maintained?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Exactly. Come out on our little balcony. You can see all the outside
wards there.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly. Come out on our little balcony. You can see all the outside\nwards there.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Nothing more to do, Nibs?
subQuotationList: ['Nothing more to do, Nibs?']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: No.
speaker: Nibs

quoteText: All right. Then we can lock up and go.
subQuotationList: ['All right. Then we can lock up and go.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: _Mon ami_ Hastings! It is indeed _mon ami_ Hastings!
subQuotationList: ['_Mon ami_ Hastings!', 'It is indeed _mon ami_ Hastings!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Poirot!
subQuotationList: ['Poirot!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
This is a very pleasant meeting for me, Miss Cynthia. This is my old
friend, Monsieur Poirot, whom I have not seen for years.
subQuotationList: ['This is a very pleasant meeting for me, Miss Cynthia. This is my old\nfriend, Monsieur Poirot, whom I have not seen for years.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, we know Monsieur Poirot, But I had no idea
he was a friend of yours.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, we know Monsieur Poirot,', 'But I had no idea\nhe was a friend of yours.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Hercule Poirot']], [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText:
Yes, indeed, I know Mademoiselle Cynthia. It
is by the charity of that good Mrs. Inglethorp that I am here. Yes, my friend, she had kindly
extended hospitality to seven of my countrypeople who, alas, are
refugees from their native land. We Belgians will always remember her
with gratitude.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, indeed,', 'I know Mademoiselle Cynthia. It
is by the charity of that good Mrs. Inglethorp that I am here.', 'Yes, my friend, she had kindly
extended hospitality to seven of my countrypeople who, alas, are
refugees from their native land. We Belgians will always remember her
with gratitude.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: He's a dear little man, I'd no idea you knew him.
subQuotationList: ["He's a dear little man,", "I'd no idea you knew him."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: You've been entertaining a celebrity unawares,
subQuotationList: ["You've been entertaining a celebrity unawares,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh, it's you,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it's you,"]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Is there anything the matter, Aunt Emily?
subQuotationList: ['Is there anything the matter, Aunt Emily?']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Certainly not, What should there be?
subQuotationList: ['Certainly not,', 'What should there be?']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Yes, m'm.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, m'm."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Don't
you think, m'm, you'd better get to bed? You're looking very tired.
subQuotationList: ["Don't\nyou think, m'm, you'd better get to bed? You're looking very tired."]
speaker: Dorcas
referringExpression: The old servant hesitated then added

quoteText:
Perhaps you're right, Dorcas   yes   no   not now. I've some letters I must
finish by post-time. Have you lighted the fire in my room as I told
you?
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps you're right, Dorcas   yes   no   not now. I've some letters I must\nfinish by post-time. Have you lighted the fire in my room as I told\nyou?"]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Yes, m'm.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, m'm."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Then I'll go to bed directly after supper.
subQuotationList: ["Then I'll go to bed directly after supper."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Goodness gracious! I wonder what's up?
subQuotationList: ["Goodness gracious! I wonder what's up?"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Had a good walk with Dr. Bauerstein?
subQuotationList: ['Had a good walk with Dr. Bauerstein?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I didn't go, Where is Mrs. Inglethorp?
subQuotationList: ["I didn't go,", 'Where is Mrs. Inglethorp?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: In the boudoir.
subQuotationList: ['In the boudoir.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Then you won't show it to me?
subQuotationList: ["Then you won't show it to me?"]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: My dear Mary, it has nothing to do with that matter.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Mary, it has nothing to do with that matter.']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Then show it to me.
subQuotationList: ['Then show it to me.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
I tell you it is not what you imagine. It does not concern you in the
least.
subQuotationList: ['I tell you it is not what you imagine. It does not concern you in the\nleast.']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText: Of course, I might have known you would shield him.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, I might have known you would shield him.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
I say! There's been the most awful row! I've got it all out of
Dorcas.
subQuotationList: ["I say! There's been the most awful row! I've got it all out of\nDorcas."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
referringExpression: Cynthia was waiting for me and greeted me eagerly with

quoteText: What kind of a row?
subQuotationList: ['What kind of a row?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Between Aunt Emily and _him_. I do hope she's found him out at last!
subQuotationList: ["Between Aunt Emily and _him_. I do hope she's found him out at last!"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Was Dorcas there, then?
subQuotationList: ['Was Dorcas there, then?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Of course not. She
subQuotationList: ['Of course not. She']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
It was a real old
bust-up. I do wish I knew what it was all about.
subQuotationList: ['It was a real old\nbust-up. I do wish I knew what it was all about.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
Aunt Emily will send him
away, and will never speak to him again.
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Emily will send him\naway, and will never speak to him again.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
referringExpression: Cynthia exhausted every possible hypothesis and cheerfully hoped

quoteText:
Send my coffee in here, Mary, I've just five minutes to
catch the post.
subQuotationList: ['Send my coffee in here, Mary,', "I've just five minutes to\ncatch the post."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
Do you young people want lights, or do you enjoy the twilight? Will you take Mrs. Inglethorp her coffee, Cynthia? I will pour
it out.
subQuotationList: ['Do you young people want lights, or do you enjoy the twilight?', 'Will you take Mrs. Inglethorp her coffee, Cynthia? I will pour\nit out.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings']], [['Miss Murdoch'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Miss Murdoch']]]

quoteText: Do not trouble, Mary, I will take it to Emily.
subQuotationList: ['Do not trouble, Mary,', 'I will take it to Emily.']
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

quoteText: It's almost too hot, We shall have a thunderstorm.
subQuotationList: ["It's almost too hot,", 'We shall have a thunderstorm.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Dr. Bauerstein! What a funny time to come.
subQuotationList: ['Dr. Bauerstein!', 'What a funny time to come.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: What have you been doing, doctor?
subQuotationList: ['What have you been doing, doctor?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
I must make my apologies, I did not really mean to
come in, but Mr. Inglethorp insisted.
subQuotationList: ['I must make my apologies,', 'I did not really mean to\ncome in, but Mr. Inglethorp insisted.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

quoteText: Well, Bauerstein, you are in a plight, Have some coffee, and tell us what you have been up to.
subQuotationList: ['Well, Bauerstein, you are in a plight,', 'Have some coffee, and tell us what you have been up to.']
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Bauerstein']], [['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Dr. Bauerstein']]]

quoteText: Thank you, I will.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, I will.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

quoteText:
The sun soon dried me off, but I'm afraid my appearance is
very disreputable.
subQuotationList: ['The sun soon dried me off,', "but I'm afraid my appearance is\nvery disreputable."]
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

quoteText: Just carry up my despatch-case, will you, dear? I'm going to bed.
subQuotationList: ["Just carry up my despatch-case, will you, dear? I'm going to bed."]
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp

quoteText:
I'll walk down to the village with you, I must
see our agent over those estate accounts. No one
need sit up. I will take the latch-key.
subQuotationList: ["I'll walk down to the village with you,", 'I must\nsee our agent over those estate accounts.', 'No one\nneed sit up. I will take the latch-key.']
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

quoteText: What's the matter?
subQuotationList: ["What's the matter?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
We are afraid my mother is very ill. She seems to be having some kind
of fit. Unfortunately she has locked herself in.
subQuotationList: ['We are afraid my mother is very ill. She seems to be having some kind\nof fit. Unfortunately she has locked herself in.']
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: I'll come at once.
subQuotationList: ["I'll come at once."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: What do you think we had better do?
subQuotationList: ['What do you think we had better do?']
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish

quoteText:
Try going through Mr. Inglethorp's room, sir, Oh, the
poor mistress! Oh, dear, sir, what ever shall we
do?
subQuotationList: ["Try going through Mr. Inglethorp's room, sir,", 'Oh, the\npoor mistress!', 'Oh, dear, sir,', 'what ever shall we\ndo?']
speaker: Dorcas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish']], [['Mrs. Inglethorp']], [['John Cavendish']], [['Dorcas', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText:
We must try and break the door in, I suppose. It'll be a tough job,
though. Here, let one of the maids go down and wake Baily and tell him
to go for Dr. Wilkins at once. Now then, we'll have a try at the door.
Half a moment, though, isn't there a door into Miss Cynthia's rooms?
subQuotationList:
["We must try and break the door in, I suppose. It'll be a tough job,
though. Here, let one of the maids go down and wake Baily and tell him
to go for Dr. Wilkins at once. Now then, we'll have a try at the door.
Half a moment, though, isn't there a door into Miss Cynthia's rooms?"]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Dr. Wilkins'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Miss Murdoch']]]

quoteText: Yes, sir, but that's always bolted. It's never been undone.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, sir, but that's always bolted. It's never been undone."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Well, we might just see.
subQuotationList: ['Well, we might just see.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
No good. That's bolted too. We must break in the door. I think this
one is a shade less solid than the one in the passage.
subQuotationList: ["No good. That's bolted too. We must break in the door. I think this\none is a shade less solid than the one in the passage."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Better now   very sudden   stupid of me   to lock myself in.
subQuotationList: ['Better now   very sudden   stupid of me   to lock myself in.']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Poor Cynthia is quite frightened,
subQuotationList: ['Poor Cynthia is quite frightened,']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
addressees: ['Mrs. Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Alfred   Alfred
subQuotationList: ['Alfred   Alfred']
speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
Ve   ry sad. Ve   ry sad, Poor dear lady. Always
did far too much   far too much   against my advice. I warned her. Her
heart was far from strong. I said to her, But no   her zeal for good works was too great. Nature
rebelled. Na   ture   re   belled.
subQuotationList:
['Ve   ry sad. Ve   ry sad,', 'Poor dear lady. Always
did far too much   far too much   against my advice. I warned her. Her
heart was far from strong.', 'I said to her,', 'But no   her zeal for good works was too great. Nature
rebelled. Na   ture   re   belled.']
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
The convulsions were of a peculiar violence, Dr. Wilkins. I am sorry
you were not here in time to witness them. They were quite   tetanic in
character.
subQuotationList: ['The convulsions were of a peculiar violence, Dr. Wilkins. I am sorry\nyou were not here in time to witness them. They were quite   tetanic in\ncharacter.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: I should like to speak to you in private, You do not object?
subQuotationList: ['I should like to speak to you in private,', 'You do not object?']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Certainly not.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly not.']
speaker: John Cavendish
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: What is it? Why did Dr. Bauerstein seem so   peculiar?
subQuotationList: ['What is it? Why did Dr. Bauerstein seem so   peculiar?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Do you know what I think?
subQuotationList: ['Do you know what I think?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Listen!
subQuotationList: ['Listen!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I believe she has been poisoned! I'm certain Dr.
Bauerstein suspects it.
subQuotationList: ["I believe she has been poisoned! I'm certain Dr.\nBauerstein suspects it."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: _What?_
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
No,
no   not that   not that!
subQuotationList: ['No,\nno   not that   not that!']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
No, no   leave me. I'd rather be alone. Let me just be quiet for a
minute or two. Go down to the others.
subQuotationList: ["No, no   leave me. I'd rather be alone. Let me just be quiet for a\nminute or two. Go down to the others."]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Where is Mr. Inglethorp?
subQuotationList: ['Where is Mr. Inglethorp?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings
referringExpression: I at last broke it by saying

quoteText: He's not in the house.
subQuotationList: ["He's not in the house."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Mr. Cavendish, I should like your consent to a post-mortem.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Cavendish, I should like your consent to a post-mortem.']
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

quoteText: Is that necessary?
subQuotationList: ['Is that necessary?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Absolutely,
subQuotationList: ['Absolutely,']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

quoteText: You mean by that      ?
subQuotationList: ['You mean by that      ?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
That neither Dr. Wilkins nor myself could give a death certificate
under the circumstances.
subQuotationList: ['That neither Dr. Wilkins nor myself could give a death certificate\nunder the circumstances.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

quoteText: In that case, I have no alternative but to agree.
subQuotationList: ['In that case, I have no alternative but to agree.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Thank you, We propose that it should take
place to-morrow night   or rather to-night. Under the circumstances, I am afraid an inquest can hardly
be avoided   these formalities are necessary, but I beg that you won't
distress yourselves.
subQuotationList:
['Thank you,', 'We propose that it should take
place to-morrow night   or rather to-night.', "Under the circumstances, I am afraid an inquest can hardly
be avoided   these formalities are necessary, but I beg that you won't
distress yourselves."]
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

quoteText:
These are the keys of the two rooms. I have locked them and, in my
opinion, they would be better kept locked for the present.
subQuotationList: ['These are the keys of the two rooms. I have locked them and, in my\nopinion, they would be better kept locked for the present.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

quoteText: John, I am going to ask you something.
subQuotationList: ['John,', 'I am going to ask you something.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
You remember my speaking of my friend Poirot? The Belgian who is here?
He has been a most famous detective.
subQuotationList: ['You remember my speaking of my friend Poirot? The Belgian who is here?\nHe has been a most famous detective.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: I want you to let me call him in   to investigate this matter.
subQuotationList: ['I want you to let me call him in   to investigate this matter.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: What   now? Before the post-mortem?
subQuotationList: ['What   now? Before the post-mortem?']

quoteText: Yes, time is an advantage if   if   there has been foul play.

course he sees them everywhere.

forgive me if I am wronging him!

curious fact, that possibly paltry little detail that will not tally,
we put it here!

quoteText:
I do not mind telling you   though, as you know, it is not my habit to
explain until the end is reached. The present contention is that Mrs.
Inglethorp died of strychnine poisoning, presumably administered in her
coffee.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Well, what time was the coffee served?

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: About eight o'clock.
subQuotationList: ["About eight o'clock."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Therefore she drank it between then and half-past eight   certainly not
much later. Well, strychnine is a fairly rapid poison. Its effects
would be felt very soon, probably in about an hour. Yet, in Mrs.
Inglethorp's case, the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five
o'clock the next morning: nine hours! But a heavy meal, taken at about
the same time as the poison, might retard its effects, though hardly to
that extent. Still, it is a possibility to be taken into account. But,
according to you, she ate very little for supper, and yet the symptoms
do not develop until early the next morning! Now that is a curious
circumstance, my friend. Something may arise at the autopsy to explain
it. In the meantime, remember it.
subQuotationList:
["Therefore she drank it between then and half-past eight   certainly not
much later. Well, strychnine is a fairly rapid poison. Its effects
would be felt very soon, probably in about an hour. Yet, in Mrs.
Inglethorp's case, the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five
o'clock the next morning: nine hours! But a heavy meal, taken at about
the same time as the poison, might retard its effects, though hardly to
that extent. Still, it is a possibility to be taken into account. But,
according to you, she ate very little for supper, and yet the symptoms
do not develop until early the next morning! Now that is a curious
circumstance, my friend. Something may arise at the autopsy to explain
it. In the meantime, remember it."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

subQuotationList: ['She was a very good mistress to me, sir.']

quoteText:
Then you will not object to answering a few questions. I put them to
you with Mr. Cavendish's full approval.
subQuotationList: ["Then you will not object to answering a few questions. I put them to\nyou with Mr. Cavendish's full approval."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, certainly, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, certainly, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Then I will begin by asking you about the events of yesterday
afternoon. Your mistress had a quarrel?
subQuotationList: ['Then I will begin by asking you about the events of yesterday\nafternoon. Your mistress had a quarrel?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, sir. But I don't know that I ought
subQuotationList: ["Yes, sir. But I don't know that I ought"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
My good Dorcas, it is necessary that I should know every detail of
that quarrel as fully as possible. Do not think that you are betraying
your mistress's secrets. Your mistress lies dead, and it is necessary
that we should know all   if we are to avenge her. Nothing can bring her
back to life, but we do hope, if there has been foul play, to bring the
murderer to justice.
subQuotationList:
["My good Dorcas, it is necessary that I should know every detail of
that quarrel as fully as possible. Do not think that you are betraying
your mistress's secrets. Your mistress lies dead, and it is necessary
that we should know all   if we are to avenge her. Nothing can bring her
back to life, but we do hope, if there has been foul play, to bring the
murderer to justice."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dorcas'], ['Dorcas'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText:
Amen to that, And, naming no names, there's
_one_ in this house that none of us could ever abide! And an ill day it
was when first _he_ darkened the threshold.
subQuotationList: ['Amen to that,', "And, naming no names, there's\n_one_ in this house that none of us could ever abide! And an ill day it\nwas when first _he_ darkened the threshold."]
speaker: Dorcas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Dorcas', 'John Cavendish', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: Now, as to this quarrel? What is the first you heard of it?
subQuotationList: ['Now, as to this quarrel? What is the first you heard of it?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, sir, I happened to be going along the hall outside yesterday
subQuotationList: ['Well, sir, I happened to be going along the hall outside yesterday']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: What time was that?
subQuotationList: ['What time was that?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I couldn't say exactly, sir, but it wasn't tea-time by a long way.
Perhaps four o'clock   or it may have been a bit later. Well, sir, as I
said, I happened to be passing along, when I heard voices very loud and
angry in here. I didn't exactly mean to listen, but   well, there it is.
I stopped. The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp
and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly.
subQuotationList:
["I couldn't say exactly, sir, but it wasn't tea-time by a long way.
Perhaps four o'clock   or it may have been a bit later. Well, sir, as I
said, I happened to be passing along, when I heard voices very loud and
angry in here. I didn't exactly mean to listen, but   well, there it is.
I stopped. The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp
and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
she said. I didn't hear what Mr. Inglethorp
replied. He spoke a good bit lower than she did   but she answered:
subQuotationList: ["she said. I didn't hear what Mr. Inglethorp\nreplied. He spoke a good bit lower than she did   but she answered:"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Again I didn't hear what he said, but she went on:
subQuotationList: ["Again I didn't hear what he said, but she went on:"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Then I
thought I heard them coming out, so I went off quickly.
subQuotationList: ['Then I\nthought I heard them coming out, so I went off quickly.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: You are sure it was Mr. Inglethorp's voice you heard?
subQuotationList: ["You are sure it was Mr. Inglethorp's voice you heard?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, yes, sir, whose else's could it be?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, yes, sir, whose else's could it be?"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Well, what happened next?
subQuotationList: ['Well, what happened next?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Later, I came back to the hall; but it was all quiet. At five o'clock,
Mrs. Inglethorp rang the bell and told me to bring her a cup of
tea   nothing to eat   to the boudoir. She was looking dreadful   so white
and upset.
subQuotationList:
["Later, I came back to the hall; but it was all quiet. At five o'clock,
Mrs. Inglethorp rang the bell and told me to bring her a cup of
tea   nothing to eat   to the boudoir. She was looking dreadful   so white
and upset."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: she says,
subQuotationList: ['she says,']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: I says.
subQuotationList: ['I says.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
She had something in her hand. I don't know if it was a letter,
or just a piece of paper, but it had writing on it, and she kept
staring at it, almost as if she couldn't believe what was written
there. She whispered to herself, as though she had forgotten I was
there:
subQuotationList:
["She had something in her hand. I don't know if it was a letter,
or just a piece of paper, but it had writing on it, and she kept
staring at it, almost as if she couldn't believe what was written
there. She whispered to herself, as though she had forgotten I was
there:"]
speaker: Dorcas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
And then she says to
me:
subQuotationList: ['And then she says to\nme:']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
I hurried off,
and got her a good strong cup of tea, and she thanked me, and said
she'd feel better when she'd drunk it.
subQuotationList: ["I hurried off,\nand got her a good strong cup of tea, and she thanked me, and said\nshe'd feel better when she'd drunk it."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
she
says.
subQuotationList: ['she\nsays.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Mrs. Cavendish came in just then, so
she didn't say any more.
subQuotationList: ["Mrs. Cavendish came in just then, so\nshe didn't say any more."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: She still had the letter, or whatever it was, in her hand?
subQuotationList: ['She still had the letter, or whatever it was, in her hand?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: What would she be likely to do with it afterwards?
subQuotationList: ['What would she be likely to do with it afterwards?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Well, I don't know, sir, I expect she would lock it up in that purple
case of hers.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I don't know, sir, I expect she would lock it up in that purple\ncase of hers."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Is that where she usually kept important papers?
subQuotationList: ['Is that where she usually kept important papers?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, sir. She brought it down with her every morning, and took it up
every night.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir. She brought it down with her every morning, and took it up\nevery night.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: When did she lose the key of it?
subQuotationList: ['When did she lose the key of it?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
She missed it yesterday at lunch-time, sir, and told me to look
carefully for it. She was very much put out about it.
subQuotationList: ['She missed it yesterday at lunch-time, sir, and told me to look\ncarefully for it. She was very much put out about it.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: But she had a duplicate key?
subQuotationList: ['But she had a duplicate key?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Never mind, Dorcas, it is my business to know things. Is this the key
that was lost?
subQuotationList: ['Never mind, Dorcas, it is my business to know things. Is this the key\nthat was lost?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
That's it, sir, right enough. But where did you find it? I looked
everywhere for it.
subQuotationList: ["That's it, sir, right enough. But where did you find it? I looked\neverywhere for it."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Ah, but you see it was not in the same place yesterday as it was
to-day. Now, to pass to another subject, had your mistress a dark green
dress in her wardrobe?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, but you see it was not in the same place yesterday as it was\nto-day. Now, to pass to another subject, had your mistress a dark green\ndress in her wardrobe?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, sir.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Are you quite sure?
subQuotationList: ['Are you quite sure?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Has anyone else in the house got a green dress?
subQuotationList: ['Has anyone else in the house got a green dress?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Miss Cynthia has a green evening dress.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Cynthia has a green evening dress.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Light or dark green?
subQuotationList: ['Light or dark green?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: A light green, sir; a sort of chiffon, they call it.
subQuotationList: ['A light green, sir; a sort of chiffon, they call it.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Ah, that is not what I want. And nobody else has anything green?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, that is not what I want. And nobody else has anything green?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, sir   not that I know of.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir   not that I know of.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Good, we will leave that and pass on. Have you any reason to believe
that your mistress was likely to take a sleeping powder last night?
subQuotationList: ['Good, we will leave that and pass on. Have you any reason to believe\nthat your mistress was likely to take a sleeping powder last night?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Not _last_ night, sir, I know she didn't.
subQuotationList: ["Not _last_ night, sir, I know she didn't."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Why do you know so positively?
subQuotationList: ['Why do you know so positively?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Because the box was empty. She took the last one two days ago, and she
didn't have any more made up.
subQuotationList: ["Because the box was empty. She took the last one two days ago, and she\ndidn't have any more made up."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: You are quite sure of that?
subQuotationList: ['You are quite sure of that?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Positive, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Positive, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Then that is cleared up! By the way, your mistress didn't ask you to
sign any paper yesterday?
subQuotationList: ["Then that is cleared up! By the way, your mistress didn't ask you to\nsign any paper yesterday?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: To sign a paper? No, sir.
subQuotationList: ['To sign a paper? No, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
When Mr. Hastings and Mr. Lawrence came in yesterday evening, they
found your mistress busy writing letters. I suppose you can give me no
idea to whom these letters were addressed?
subQuotationList: ['When Mr. Hastings and Mr. Lawrence came in yesterday evening, they\nfound your mistress busy writing letters. I suppose you can give me no\nidea to whom these letters were addressed?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Dorcas']]]

quoteText:
I'm afraid I couldn't, sir. I was out in the evening. Perhaps Annie
could tell you, though she's a careless girl. Never cleared the
coffee-cups away last night. That's what happens when I'm not here to
look after things.
subQuotationList:
["I'm afraid I couldn't, sir. I was out in the evening. Perhaps Annie
could tell you, though she's a careless girl. Never cleared the
coffee-cups away last night. That's what happens when I'm not here to
look after things."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Since they have been left, Dorcas, leave them a little longer, I pray
you. I should like to examine them.
subQuotationList: ['Since they have been left, Dorcas, leave them a little longer, I pray\nyou. I should like to examine them.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Very well, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Very well, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: What time did you go out last evening?
subQuotationList: ['What time did you go out last evening?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: About six o'clock, sir.
subQuotationList: ["About six o'clock, sir."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Thank you, Dorcas, that is all I have to ask you.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, Dorcas, that is all I have to ask you.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I have been admiring these flower beds. How
many gardeners are employed here, by the way?
subQuotationList: ['I have been admiring these flower beds. How\nmany gardeners are employed here, by the way?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Only three now, sir. Five, we had, before the war, when it was kept as
a gentleman's place should be. I wish you could have seen it then, sir.
A fair sight it was. But now there's only old Manning, and young
William, and a new-fashioned woman gardener in breeches and such-like.
Ah, these are dreadful times!
subQuotationList:
["Only three now, sir. Five, we had, before the war, when it was kept as
a gentleman's place should be. I wish you could have seen it then, sir.
A fair sight it was. But now there's only old Manning, and young
William, and a new-fashioned woman gardener in breeches and such-like.
Ah, these are dreadful times!"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
The good times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now,
will you send Annie to me here?
subQuotationList: ['The good times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now,\nwill you send Annie to me here?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
How did you know that Mrs. Inglethorp took sleeping powders? And about the lost key
and the duplicate?
subQuotationList: ['How did you know that Mrs. Inglethorp took sleeping powders?', 'And about the lost key\nand the duplicate?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: One thing at a time. As to the sleeping powders, I knew by this.
subQuotationList: ['One thing at a time. As to the sleeping powders, I knew by this.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Where did you find it?
subQuotationList: ['Where did you find it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
In the wash-stand drawer in Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom. It was Number
Six of my catalogue.
subQuotationList: ["In the wash-stand drawer in Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom. It was Number\nSix of my catalogue."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
But I suppose, as the last powder was taken two days ago, it is not of
much importance?
subQuotationList: ['But I suppose, as the last powder was taken two days ago, it is not of\nmuch importance?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Probably not, but do you notice anything that strikes you as peculiar
about this box?
subQuotationList: ['Probably not, but do you notice anything that strikes you as peculiar\nabout this box?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, I can't say that I do.
subQuotationList: ["No, I can't say that I do."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Look at the label.
subQuotationList: ['Look at the label.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, I see nothing unusual.
subQuotationList: ['No, I see nothing unusual.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Not the fact that there is no chemist's name?
subQuotationList: ["Not the fact that there is no chemist's name?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Ah! To be sure, that is odd!
subQuotationList: ['Ah!', 'To be sure, that is odd!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Have you ever known a chemist to send out a box like that, without his
printed name?
subQuotationList: ['Have you ever known a chemist to send out a box like that, without his\nprinted name?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, I can't say that I have.
subQuotationList: ["No, I can't say that I have."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Yet the explanation is quite simple. So do not intrigue yourself, my
friend.
subQuotationList: ['Yet the explanation is quite simple. So do not intrigue yourself, my\nfriend.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
referringExpression: Poirot damped my ardour by remarking

quoteText:
I sent for you, Annie, because I thought you might be able to tell me
something about the letters Mrs. Inglethorp wrote last night. How many
were there? And can you tell me any of the names and addresses?
subQuotationList: ['I sent for you, Annie, because I thought you might be able to tell me\nsomething about the letters Mrs. Inglethorp wrote last night. How many\nwere there? And can you tell me any of the names and addresses?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
There were four letters, sir. One was to Miss Howard, and one was to
Mr. Wells, the lawyer, and the other two I don't think I remember,
sir   oh, yes, one was to Ross's, the caterers in Tadminster. The other
one, I don't remember.
subQuotationList:
["There were four letters, sir. One was to Miss Howard, and one was to
Mr. Wells, the lawyer, and the other two I don't think I remember,
sir   oh, yes, one was to Ross's, the caterers in Tadminster. The other
one, I don't remember."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText: Think,
subQuotationList: ['Think,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I'm sorry, sir, but it's clean gone. I don't think I can have noticed
it.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry, sir, but it's clean gone. I don't think I can have noticed\nit."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
It does not matter, Now I want to ask you about something else. There is a
saucepan in Mrs. Inglethorp's room with some cocoa in it. Did she have
that every night?
subQuotationList: ['It does not matter,', "Now I want to ask you about something else. There is a\nsaucepan in Mrs. Inglethorp's room with some cocoa in it. Did she have\nthat every night?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, sir, it was put in her room every evening, and she warmed it up
in the night   whenever she fancied it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, it was put in her room every evening, and she warmed it up\nin the night   whenever she fancied it.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: What was it? Plain cocoa?
subQuotationList: ['What was it? Plain cocoa?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, sir, made with milk, with a teaspoonful of sugar, and two
teaspoonfuls of rum in it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, made with milk, with a teaspoonful of sugar, and two\nteaspoonfuls of rum in it.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: Who took it to her room?
subQuotationList: ['Who took it to her room?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I did, sir.
subQuotationList: ['I did, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: Always?
subQuotationList: ['Always?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: At what time?
subQuotationList: ['At what time?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: When I went to draw the curtains, as a rule, sir.
subQuotationList: ['When I went to draw the curtains, as a rule, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: Did you bring it straight up from the kitchen then?
subQuotationList: ['Did you bring it straight up from the kitchen then?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
No, sir, you see there's not much room on the gas stove, so cook used
to make it early, before putting the vegetables on for supper. Then I
used to bring it up, and put it on the table by the swing door, and
take it into her room later.
subQuotationList:
["No, sir, you see there's not much room on the gas stove, so cook used
to make it early, before putting the vegetables on for supper. Then I
used to bring it up, and put it on the table by the swing door, and
take it into her room later."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText: The swing door is in the left wing, is it not?
subQuotationList: ['The swing door is in the left wing, is it not?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
And the table, is it on this side of the door, or on the
farther   servants' side?
subQuotationList: ["And the table, is it on this side of the door, or on the\nfarther   servants' side?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: It's this side, sir.
subQuotationList: ["It's this side, sir."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText: What time did you bring it up last night?
subQuotationList: ['What time did you bring it up last night?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: About quarter-past seven, I should say, sir.
subQuotationList: ['About quarter-past seven, I should say, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: And when did you take it into Mrs. Inglethorp's room?
subQuotationList: ["And when did you take it into Mrs. Inglethorp's room?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
When I went to shut up, sir. About eight o'clock. Mrs. Inglethorp came
up to bed before I'd finished.
subQuotationList: ["When I went to shut up, sir. About eight o'clock. Mrs. Inglethorp came\nup to bed before I'd finished."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
Then, between seven-fifteen and eight o'clock, the cocoa was standing
on the table in the left wing?
subQuotationList: ["Then, between seven-fifteen and eight o'clock, the cocoa was standing\non the table in the left wing?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
And if there _was_ salt in it, sir, it wasn't me. I never took the
salt near it.
subQuotationList: ["And if there _was_ salt in it, sir, it wasn't me. I never took the\nsalt near it."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText: What makes you think there was salt in it?
subQuotationList: ['What makes you think there was salt in it?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Seeing it on the tray, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Seeing it on the tray, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: You saw some salt on the tray?
subQuotationList: ['You saw some salt on the tray?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes. Coarse kitchen salt, it looked. I never noticed it when I took
the tray up, but when I came to take it into the mistress's room I saw
it at once, and I suppose I ought to have taken it down again, and
asked cook to make some fresh. But I was in a hurry, because Dorcas was
out, and I thought maybe the cocoa itself was all right, and the salt
had only gone on the tray. So I dusted it off with my apron, and took
it in.
subQuotationList:
["Yes. Coarse kitchen salt, it looked. I never noticed it when I took
the tray up, but when I came to take it into the mistress's room I saw
it at once, and I suppose I ought to have taken it down again, and
asked cook to make some fresh. But I was in a hurry, because Dorcas was
out, and I thought maybe the cocoa itself was all right, and the salt
had only gone on the tray. So I dusted it off with my apron, and took
it in."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
When you went into Mrs. Inglethorp's room, was the door leading into
Miss Cynthia's room bolted?
subQuotationList: ["When you went into Mrs. Inglethorp's room, was the door leading into\nMiss Cynthia's room bolted?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh! Yes, sir; it always was. It had never been opened.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Yes, sir; it always was. It had never been opened.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
And the door into Mr. Inglethorp's room? Did you notice if that was
bolted too?
subQuotationList: ["And the door into Mr. Inglethorp's room? Did you notice if that was\nbolted too?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I couldn't rightly say, sir; it was shut but I couldn't say whether it
was bolted or not.
subQuotationList: ["I couldn't rightly say, sir; it was shut but I couldn't say whether it\nwas bolted or not."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
When you finally left the room, did Mrs. Inglethorp bolt the door
after you?
subQuotationList: ['When you finally left the room, did Mrs. Inglethorp bolt the door\nafter you?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
No, sir, not then, but I expect she did later. She usually did lock it
at night. The door into the passage, that is.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir, not then, but I expect she did later. She usually did lock it\nat night. The door into the passage, that is.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
Did you notice any candle grease on the floor when you did the room
yesterday?
subQuotationList: ['Did you notice any candle grease on the floor when you did the room\nyesterday?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn't have a candle, only
a reading-lamp.
subQuotationList: ["Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn't have a candle, only\na reading-lamp."]
speaker: Annie

quoteText:
Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor,
you think you would have been sure to have seen it?
subQuotationList: ['Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor,\nyou think you would have been sure to have seen it?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper
and a hot iron.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper\nand a hot iron.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: Did your mistress ever have a green dress?
subQuotationList: ['Did your mistress ever have a green dress?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, sir.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: Nor a mantle, nor a cape, nor a   how do you call it?   a sports coat?

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Not green, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Not green, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: No, sir.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: You are sure of that?

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Quite sure.
subQuotationList: ['Quite sure.']
speaker: Annie

quoteText: _Bien!_ That is all I want to know. Thank you very much.

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Poirot, I congratulate you! This is a great discovery.

quoteText: What is a great discovery?
subQuotationList: ['What is a great discovery?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That
explains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early
morning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night.
subQuotationList: ['Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That\nexplains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early\nmorning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
So you think that the cocoa   mark well what I say, Hastings, the
_cocoa_   contained strychnine?
subQuotationList: ['So you think that the cocoa   mark well what I say, Hastings, the\n_cocoa_   contained strychnine?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Of course! That salt on the tray, what else could it have been?
