must leave no stone unturned']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings?
He has just rushed past me like a mad bull.
subQuotationList: ['What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings?\nHe has just rushed past me like a mad bull.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: He's rather upset about something,
subQuotationList: ["He's rather upset about something,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: They haven't met yet, have they?
subQuotationList: ["They haven't met yet, have they?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
referringExpression: I endeavoured to try and turn the conversation by saying

quoteText: Who?
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Mr. Inglethorp and Miss Howard.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Inglethorp and Miss Howard.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Do you think it would be such a disaster if they did meet?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think it would be such a disaster if they did meet?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Well, don't you?
subQuotationList: ["Well, don't you?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
I should like to see a good
flare up. It would clear the air. At present we are all thinking so
much, and saying so little.
subQuotationList: ['I should like to see a good\nflare up. It would clear the air. At present we are all thinking so\nmuch, and saying so little.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Cavendish', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: John doesn't think so, He's anxious to keep them apart.
subQuotationList: ["John doesn't think so,", "He's anxious to keep them apart."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh, John!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, John!']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Old John's an awfully good sort.
subQuotationList: ["Old John's an awfully good sort."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: You are loyal to your friend. I like you for that.
subQuotationList: ['You are loyal to your friend. I like you for that.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
referringExpression: She studied me curiously for a minute or two and then said

quoteText: Aren't you my friend too?
subQuotationList: ["Aren't you my friend too?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I am a very bad friend.
subQuotationList: ['I am a very bad friend.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Why do you say that?
subQuotationList: ['Why do you say that?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Because it is true. I am charming to my friends one day, and forget
all about them the next.
subQuotationList: ['Because it is true. I am charming to my friends one day, and forget\nall about them the next.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Yet you seem to be invariably charming to Dr. Bauerstein!
subQuotationList: ['Yet you seem to be invariably charming to Dr. Bauerstein!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
My dear fellow, is this wise? Surely you don't want the
whole house to know of this occurrence? You are actually playing into
the criminal's hands.
subQuotationList: ['My dear fellow,', "is this wise? Surely you don't want the\nwhole house to know of this occurrence? You are actually playing into\nthe criminal's hands."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: You think so, Hastings?
subQuotationList: ['You think so, Hastings?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I am sure of it.
subQuotationList: ['I am sure of it.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Well, well, my friend, I will be guided by you.
subQuotationList: ['Well, well, my friend, I will be guided by you.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Good. Although, unfortunately, it is a little too late now.
subQuotationList: ['Good. Although, unfortunately, it is a little too late now.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Sure.
subQuotationList: ['Sure.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, let us go, _mon ami_.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'let us go, _mon ami_.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You have finished here?
subQuotationList: ['You have finished here?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: For the moment, yes. You will walk back with me to the village?
subQuotationList: ['For the moment, yes. You will walk back with me to the village?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Willingly.
subQuotationList: ['Willingly.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Excuse me, mademoiselle, one minute.
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me, mademoiselle, one minute.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Did you ever make up Mrs. Inglethorp's medicines?
subQuotationList: ["Did you ever make up Mrs. Inglethorp's medicines?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No.
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Only her powders?
subQuotationList: ['Only her powders?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, yes, I did make up some sleeping powders for her once.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, I did make up some sleeping powders for her once.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: These?
subQuotationList: ['These?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Can you tell me what they were? Sulphonal? Veronal?
subQuotationList: ['Can you tell me what they were? Sulphonal? Veronal?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, they were bromide powders.
subQuotationList: ['No, they were bromide powders.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Ah! Thank you, mademoiselle; good morning.
subQuotationList: ['Ah! Thank you, mademoiselle; good morning.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
My friend, I have a little idea, a very
strange, and probably utterly impossible idea. And yet   it fits in.
subQuotationList: ['My friend,', 'I have a little idea, a very\nstrange, and probably utterly impossible idea. And yet   it fits in.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
So that is the explanation of the blank label on the box, Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it
myself.
subQuotationList: ['So that is the explanation of the blank label on the box,', 'Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it\nmyself.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
They have made one more discovery, _l  -bas_, Mr. Wells told me
as we were going upstairs.
subQuotationList: ['They have made one more discovery, _l  -bas_,', 'Mr. Wells told me\nas we were going upstairs.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells']], [['Mr. Wells'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Wells', 'Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText: What was it?
subQuotationList: ['What was it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs.
Inglethorp's, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred
Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged.
It came quite as a surprise to Wells   and to John Cavendish also. It was
written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the
servants   not Dorcas.
subQuotationList:
["Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs.
Inglethorp's, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred
Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged.
It came quite as a surprise to Wells   and to John Cavendish also. It was
written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the
servants   not Dorcas."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp', 'Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Wells'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Dorcas']]]

quoteText: Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?
subQuotationList: ['Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: He says not.
subQuotationList: ['He says not.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
One might take that with a grain of salt, All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled
words on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made
yesterday afternoon?
subQuotationList: ['One might take that with a grain of salt,', 'All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled\nwords on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made\nyesterday afternoon?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
_Mon ami_, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the
fact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?
subQuotationList: ['_Mon ami_, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the\nfact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, often. I suppose everyone has.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, often. I suppose everyone has.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or
twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to
see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You
will notice that the word    possessed' is spelt first with one    s' and
subsequently with two   correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it
in a sentence, thus:
subQuotationList:
["Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or
twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to
see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You
will notice that the word    possessed' is spelt first with one    s' and
subsequently with two   correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it
in a sentence, thus:"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Now, what did that tell me? It
told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word    possessed' that
afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh
in my mind, the possibility of a will   (a document almost certain to
contain that word)   occurred to me at once. This possibility was
confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the
boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several
traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine
for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy
deposit.
subQuotationList:
["Now, what did that tell me? It
told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word    possessed' that
afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh
in my mind, the possibility of a will   (a document almost certain to
contain that word)   occurred to me at once. This possibility was
confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the
boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several
traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine
for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy
deposit."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had
been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that
on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they _had_
been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly
both of the gardeners   for there were two sets of footprints in the
bed   had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished
to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window,
and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite
convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two
gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right
in my supposition.
subQuotationList:
['I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had
been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that
on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they _had_
been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly
both of the gardeners   for there were two sets of footprints in the
bed   had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished
to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window,
and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite
convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two
gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right
in my supposition.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
That was very ingenious, I must confess
that the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite
erroneous.
subQuotationList: ['That was very ingenious,', 'I must confess\nthat the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite\nerroneous.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good
servant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most
likely.
subQuotationList: ['You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good\nservant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most\nlikely.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Another point   how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had
been lost?
subQuotationList: ['Another point   how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had\nbeen lost?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You
observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That
suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy
key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would
at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what
was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to
the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the
lock of the despatch-case.
subQuotationList:
['I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You
observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That
suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy
key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would
at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what
was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to
the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the
lock of the despatch-case.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: You are very sure of his guilt?
subQuotationList: ['You are very sure of his guilt?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more
clearly.
subQuotationList: ['Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more\nclearly.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
On the contrary, there are several points in
his favour.
subQuotationList: ['On the contrary,', 'there are several points in\nhis favour.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, come now!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, come now!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I see only one.
subQuotationList: ['I see only one.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: And that?
subQuotationList: ['And that?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: That he was not in the house last night.
subQuotationList: ['That he was not in the house last night.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Bad shot!' as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to
my mind tells against him.
subQuotationList: ["Bad shot!' as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to\nmy mind tells against him."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: How is that?
subQuotationList: ['How is that?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last
night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His
excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two
possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a
reason of his own for his absence.
subQuotationList:
['Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last
night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His
excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two
possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a
reason of his own for his absence.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: And that reason?
subQuotationList: ['And that reason?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp,
I should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel   but that does not of necessity
make him a murderer.
subQuotationList: ['How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp,\nI should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel   but that does not of necessity\nmake him a murderer.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
We do not agree, eh? Well, let us leave it. Time will
show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the
case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom
were bolted on the inside?
subQuotationList:
['We do not agree, eh?', 'Well, let us leave it. Time will
show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the
case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom
were bolted on the inside?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot']], [['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: Well One must look at it logically.
subQuotationList: ['Well', 'One must look at it logically.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: True.
subQuotationList: ['True.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I should put it this way. The doors _were_ bolted   our own eyes have
told us that   yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and
the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone
entered the room. You agree so far?
subQuotationList:
['I should put it this way. The doors _were_ bolted   our own eyes have
told us that   yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and
the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone
entered the room. You agree so far?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed.
subQuotationList: ['Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Well, as the person who entered did not do so by
the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have
been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens
the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would
naturally open the door to her own husband.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', 'as the person who entered did not do so by
the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have
been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens
the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would
naturally open the door to her own husband.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room   a most
unusual proceeding on her part   she had had a most violent quarrel with
him that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit.
subQuotationList: ['Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room   a most\nunusual proceeding on her part   she had had a most violent quarrel with\nhim that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs.
Inglethorp herself?
subQuotationList: ['But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs.\nInglethorp herself?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door
into the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards
morning, and bolted it then.
subQuotationList: ['There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door\ninto the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards\nmorning, and bolted it then.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?
subQuotationList: ['Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another
feature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard
between Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?
subQuotationList: ['No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another\nfeature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard\nbetween Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I had forgotten that, That is as enigmatical as
ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and
reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was
certainly not her affair.
subQuotationList:
['I had forgotten that,', 'That is as enigmatical as
ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and
reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was
certainly not her affair.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to
do.
subQuotationList: ['Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to\ndo.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
It is certainly curious, Still, it is unimportant, and
need not be taken into account.
subQuotationList: ['It is certainly curious,', 'Still, it is unimportant, and\nneed not be taken into account.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If
the fact will not fit the theory   let the theory go.
subQuotationList: ['What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If\nthe fact will not fit the theory   let the theory go.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, we shall see,
subQuotationList: ['Well, we shall see,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes, we shall see.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, we shall see.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Look, Poirot!
subQuotationList: ['Look, Poirot!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
_Tiens!_ It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist's shop. He is
coming here.
subQuotationList: ['_Tiens!_', "It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist's shop. He is\ncoming here."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: A little minute, I come.
subQuotationList: ['A little minute,', 'I come.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Oh, Mr. Poirot, I'm sorry for the inconvenience, but I heard that
you'd just come back from the Hall?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, Mr. Poirot, I'm sorry for the inconvenience, but I heard that\nyou'd just come back from the Hall?"]
speaker: Mr. Mace

quoteText: Yes, we have.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, we have.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
It's all over the village about old Mrs. Inglethorp dying so suddenly.
They do say
subQuotationList: ["It's all over the village about old Mrs. Inglethorp dying so suddenly.\nThey do say"]
speaker: Mr. Mace

quoteText: that it's poison?
subQuotationList: ["that it's poison?"]
speaker: Mr. Mace

quoteText: Only the doctors can tell us that, Mr. Mace.
subQuotationList: ['Only the doctors can tell us that, Mr. Mace.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, exactly   of course
subQuotationList: ['Yes, exactly   of course']
speaker: Mr. Mace

quoteText:
Just tell me this, Mr. Poirot, it isn't   it
isn't strychnine, is it?
subQuotationList: ["Just tell me this, Mr. Poirot, it isn't   it\nisn't strychnine, is it?"]
speaker: Mr. Mace

quoteText:
Yes, He will have evidence to give at the
inquest.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'He will have evidence to give at the\ninquest.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Not now, not now, _mon ami_. I have need of reflection. My mind is in
some disorder   which is not well.
subQuotationList: ['Not now, not now, _mon ami_. I have need of reflection. My mind is in\nsome disorder   which is not well.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and
classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear
yet   no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles _me_. _Me_,
Hercule Poirot! There are two facts of significance.
subQuotationList:
['It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and
classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear
yet   no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles _me_. _Me_,
Hercule Poirot! There are two facts of significance.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: And what are they?
subQuotationList: ['And what are they?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very
important.
subQuotationList: ['The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very\nimportant.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
But it was a glorious day! Poirot, you're pulling my
leg!
subQuotationList: ['But it was a glorious day!', "Poirot, you're pulling my\nleg!"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not
forget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!
subQuotationList: ['Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not\nforget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: And the second point?
subQuotationList: ['And the second point?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
The important fact that Monsieur Inglethorp wears very peculiar
clothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses.
subQuotationList: ['The important fact that Monsieur Inglethorp wears very peculiar\nclothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Poirot, I cannot believe you are serious.
subQuotationList: ['Poirot, I cannot believe you are serious.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I am absolutely serious, my friend.
subQuotationList: ['I am absolutely serious, my friend.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But this is childish!
subQuotationList: ['But this is childish!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No, it is very momentous.
subQuotationList: ['No, it is very momentous.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
And supposing the Coroner's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder
against Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?
subQuotationList: ["And supposing the Coroner's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder\nagainst Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
They would not be shaken because twelve stupid men had happened to
make a mistake! But that will not occur. For one thing, a country jury
is not anxious to take responsibility upon itself, and Mr. Inglethorp
stands practically in the position of local squire. Also, _I_ should not allow it!
subQuotationList:
['They would not be shaken because twelve stupid men had happened to
make a mistake! But that will not occur. For one thing, a country jury
is not anxious to take responsibility upon itself, and Mr. Inglethorp
stands practically in the position of local squire. Also,', '_I_ should not allow it!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: _You_ would not allow it?
subQuotationList: ['_You_ would not allow it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, yes, _mon ami_, I would do what I say.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, _mon ami_, I would do what I say.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs.
Inglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved   no. But she was
very good to us Belgians   I owe her a debt.
subQuotationList: ['In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs.\nInglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved   no. But she was\nvery good to us Belgians   I owe her a debt.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You'm from the Hall, bain't you?
subQuotationList: ["You'm from the Hall, bain't you?"]
speaker: An Aged Rustic

quoteText:
Yes. I'm looking for a friend of mine whom I thought might have walked
this way.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. I'm looking for a friend of mine whom I thought might have walked\nthis way."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
A little chap? As waves his hands when he talks? One of them Belgies
from the village?
subQuotationList: ['A little chap? As waves his hands when he talks? One of them Belgies\nfrom the village?']
speaker: An Aged Rustic
mentionTextsList: [['A little chap', 'his', 'he', 'One of them Belgies\nfrom the village']]

quoteText: Yes, He has been here, then?
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'He has been here, then?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, ay, he's been here, right enough. More'n once too. Friend of
yours, is he? Ah, you gentlemen from the Hall   you'm a pretty lot!
subQuotationList: ["Oh, ay, he's been here, right enough. More'n once too. Friend of\nyours, is he? Ah, you gentlemen from the Hall   you'm a pretty lot!"]
speaker: An Aged Rustic
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: Why, do the gentlemen from the Hall come here often?
subQuotationList: ['Why, do the gentlemen from the Hall come here often?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
_One_ does, mister. Naming no names, mind. And a very liberal
gentleman too! Oh, thank you, sir, I'm sure.
subQuotationList: ["_One_ does, mister. Naming no names, mind. And a very liberal\ngentleman too! Oh, thank you, sir, I'm sure."]
speaker: An Aged Rustic

quoteText: Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?
subQuotationList: ['Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
I should consider it very unlikely. Strychnine is not used for
domestic purposes, as some poisons are, and there are restrictions
placed on its sale.
subQuotationList: ['I should consider it very unlikely. Strychnine is not used for\ndomestic purposes, as some poisons are, and there are restrictions\nplaced on its sale.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Does anything in your examination lead you to determine how the poison
was administered?
subQuotationList: ['Does anything in your examination lead you to determine how the poison\nwas administered?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: No.
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: You arrived at Styles before Dr. Wilkins, I believe?
subQuotationList: ['You arrived at Styles before Dr. Wilkins, I believe?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
That is so. The motor met me just outside the lodge gates, and I
hurried there as fast as I could.
subQuotationList: ['That is so. The motor met me just outside the lodge gates, and I\nhurried there as fast as I could.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Will you relate to us exactly what happened next?
subQuotationList: ['Will you relate to us exactly what happened next?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells']]]

quoteText:
I entered Mrs. Inglethorp's room. She was at that moment in a typical
tetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out:
subQuotationList: ["I entered Mrs. Inglethorp's room. She was at that moment in a typical\ntetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out:"]
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Could the strychnine have been administered in Mrs. Inglethorp's
after-dinner coffee which was taken to her by her husband?
subQuotationList: ["Could the strychnine have been administered in Mrs. Inglethorp's\nafter-dinner coffee which was taken to her by her husband?"]
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Possibly, but strychnine is a fairly rapid drug in its action. The
symptoms appear from one to two hours after it has been swallowed. It
is retarded under certain conditions, none of which, however, appear to
have been present in this case. I presume Mrs. Inglethorp took the
coffee after dinner about eight o'clock, whereas the symptoms did not
manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning, which, on the
face of it, points to the drug having been taken much later in the
evening.
subQuotationList:
["Possibly, but strychnine is a fairly rapid drug in its action. The
symptoms appear from one to two hours after it has been swallowed. It
is retarded under certain conditions, none of which, however, appear to
have been present in this case. I presume Mrs. Inglethorp took the
coffee after dinner about eight o'clock, whereas the symptoms did not
manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning, which, on the
face of it, points to the drug having been taken much later in the
evening."]
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Mrs. Inglethorp was in the habit of drinking a cup of cocoa in the
middle of the night. Could the strychnine have been administered in
that?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Inglethorp was in the habit of drinking a cup of cocoa in the\nmiddle of the night. Could the strychnine have been administered in\nthat?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
No, I myself took a sample of the cocoa remaining in the saucepan and
had it analysed. There was no strychnine present.
subQuotationList: ['No, I myself took a sample of the cocoa remaining in the saucepan and\nhad it analysed. There was no strychnine present.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: How did you know?
subQuotationList: ['How did you know?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Listen.
subQuotationList: ['Listen.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I should say that I would have been
considerably surprised at any other result.
subQuotationList: ['I should say', 'that I would have been\nconsiderably surprised at any other result.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Simply because strychnine has an unusually bitter taste. It can be
detected in a solution of one in seventy thousand, and can only be
disguised by some strongly flavoured substance. Cocoa would be quite
powerless to mask it.
subQuotationList:
['Simply because strychnine has an unusually bitter taste. It can be
detected in a solution of one in seventy thousand, and can only be
disguised by some strongly flavoured substance. Cocoa would be quite
powerless to mask it.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
No. Coffee has a bitter taste of its own which would probably cover
the taste of strychnine.
subQuotationList: ['No. Coffee has a bitter taste of its own which would probably cover\nthe taste of strychnine.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Then you consider it more likely that the drug was administered in the
coffee, but that for some unknown reason its action was delayed.
subQuotationList: ['Then you consider it more likely that the drug was administered in the\ncoffee, but that for some unknown reason its action was delayed.']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Yes, but, the cup being completely smashed, there is no possibility of
analyzing its contents.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but, the cup being completely smashed, there is no possibility of\nanalyzing its contents.']
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: I should like to make a suggestion if I may?
subQuotationList: ['I should like to make a suggestion if I may?']
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Certainly, Mr. Cavendish, we are here to arrive at the truth of this
matter, and welcome anything that may lead to further elucidation.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, Mr. Cavendish, we are here to arrive at the truth of this\nmatter, and welcome anything that may lead to further elucidation.']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
It is just an idea of mine, Of course I may be
quite wrong, but it still seems to me that my mother's death might be
accounted for by natural means.
subQuotationList: ['It is just an idea of mine,', "Of course I may be\nquite wrong, but it still seems to me that my mother's death might be\naccounted for by natural means."]
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: How do you make that out, Mr. Cavendish?
subQuotationList: ['How do you make that out, Mr. Cavendish?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
My mother, at the time of her death, and for some time before it, was
taking a tonic containing strychnine.
subQuotationList: ['My mother, at the time of her death, and for some time before it, was\ntaking a tonic containing strychnine.']
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
I believe, that there have been cases where the
cumulative effect of a drug, administered for some time, has ended by
causing death. Also, is it not possible that she may have taken an
overdose of her medicine by accident?
subQuotationList:
['I believe,', 'that there have been cases where the
cumulative effect of a drug, administered for some time, has ended by
causing death. Also, is it not possible that she may have taken an
overdose of her medicine by accident?']
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
This is the first we have heard of the deceased taking strychnine at
the time of her death. We are much obliged to you, Mr. Cavendish.
subQuotationList: ['This is the first we have heard of the deceased taking strychnine at\nthe time of her death. We are much obliged to you, Mr. Cavendish.']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
What Mr. Cavendish suggests is quite impossible. Any doctor would tell
you the same. Strychnine is, in a certain sense, a cumulative poison,
but it would be quite impossible for it to result in sudden death in
this way. There would have to be a long period of chronic symptoms
which would at once have attracted my attention. The whole thing is
absurd.
subQuotationList:
['What Mr. Cavendish suggests is quite impossible. Any doctor would tell
you the same. Strychnine is, in a certain sense, a cumulative poison,
but it would be quite impossible for it to result in sudden death in
this way. There would have to be a long period of chronic symptoms
which would at once have attracted my attention. The whole thing is
absurd.']
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
referringExpression: Dr Wilkins was recalled and ridiculed

quoteText:
And the second suggestion? That Mrs. Inglethorp may have inadvertently
taken an overdose?
subQuotationList: ['And the second suggestion? That Mrs. Inglethorp may have inadvertently\ntaken an overdose?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Three, or even four doses, would not have resulted in death. Mrs.
Inglethorp always had an extra large amount of medicine made up at a
time, as she dealt with Coot's, the Cash Chemists in Tadminster. She
would have had to take very nearly the whole bottle to account for the
amount of strychnine found at the post-mortem.
subQuotationList:
["Three, or even four doses, would not have resulted in death. Mrs.
Inglethorp always had an extra large amount of medicine made up at a
time, as she dealt with Coot's, the Cash Chemists in Tadminster. She
would have had to take very nearly the whole bottle to account for the
amount of strychnine found at the post-mortem."]
speaker: Dr. Wilkins
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Then you consider that we may dismiss the tonic as not being in any
way instrumental in causing her death?
subQuotationList: ['Then you consider that we may dismiss the tonic as not being in any\nway instrumental in causing her death?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cynthia', 'Dorcas', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Evie', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mr. Wells'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: Certainly. The supposition is ridiculous.

myself.

On Monday evening last, did you purchase strychnine for the purpose of
poisoning a dog?

speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
No, I did not. There is no dog at Styles, except an outdoor sheepdog,
which is in perfect health.

speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

You deny absolutely having purchased strychnine from Albert Mace on
Monday last?

show you.

again.

That is a pity, I am to take it then that
you decline to say where you were at the time that Mr. Mace positively
recognized you as entering the shop to purchase strychnine?

quoteText: Be careful, Mr. Inglethorp.

quoteText:
_Sacr  !_ Does this imbecile of a man _want_ to be
arrested?
subQuotationList: ['_Sacr  !_', 'Does this imbecile of a man _want_ to be\narrested?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You had a discussion with your wife on Tuesday afternoon?
subQuotationList: ['You had a discussion with your wife on Tuesday afternoon?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
Pardon me, you have been misinformed.
I had no quarrel with my dear wife. The whole story is absolutely
untrue. I was absent from the house the entire afternoon.
subQuotationList: ['Pardon me,', 'you have been misinformed.\nI had no quarrel with my dear wife. The whole story is absolutely\nuntrue. I was absent from the house the entire afternoon.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Have you anyone who can testify to that?
subQuotationList: ['Have you anyone who can testify to that?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

subQuotationList: ['You have my word,']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
There are two witnesses who will swear to having heard your
disagreement with Mrs. Inglethorp.

speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

subQuotationList: ['Those witnesses were mistaken.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp

quoteText:
Mr. Inglethorp, you have heard your wife's dying
words repeated here. Can you explain them in any way?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Inglethorp,', "you have heard your wife's dying\nwords repeated here. Can you explain them in any way?"]
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Certainly I can.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly I can.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: You can?
subQuotationList: ['You can?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
It seems to me very simple. The room was dimly lighted. Dr. Bauerstein
is much of my height and build, and, like me, wears a beard. In the dim
light, and suffering as she was, my poor wife mistook him for me.
subQuotationList: ['It seems to me very simple. The room was dimly lighted. Dr. Bauerstein\nis much of my height and build, and, like me, wears a beard. In the dim\nlight, and suffering as she was, my poor wife mistook him for me.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Ah! But it is an idea, that!
subQuotationList: ['Ah!', 'But it is an idea, that!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You think it is true?
subQuotationList: ['You think it is true?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I do not say that. But it is truly an ingenious supposition.
subQuotationList: ['I do not say that. But it is truly an ingenious supposition.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You read my wife's last words as an accusation they were, on the contrary, an appeal to me.
subQuotationList: ["You read my wife's last words as an accusation", 'they were, on the contrary, an appeal to me.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
I believe, Mr. Inglethorp, that you yourself poured out the coffee,
and took it to your wife that evening?
subQuotationList: ['I believe, Mr. Inglethorp, that you yourself poured out the coffee,\nand took it to your wife that evening?']
speaker: Mr. Wells
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
I poured it out, yes. But I did not take it to her. I meant to do so,
but I was told that a friend was at the hall door, so I laid down the
coffee on the hall table. When I came through the hall again a few
minutes later, it was gone.
subQuotationList:
['I poured it out, yes. But I did not take it to her. I meant to do so,
but I was told that a friend was at the hall door, so I laid down the

speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Dr. Wilkins', 'Mr. Mace', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Japp', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Dr. Bauerstein', 'Mr. Hastings', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Do you know who that little man is?
subQuotationList: ['Do you know who that little man is?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
That is Detective Inspector James Japp of Scotland Yard   Jimmy Japp.
The other man is from Scotland Yard too. Things are moving quickly, my
friend.
subQuotationList: ['That is Detective Inspector James Japp of Scotland Yard   Jimmy Japp.\nThe other man is from Scotland Yard too. Things are moving quickly, my\nfriend.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionTextsList: [['Detective Inspector James Japp of Scotland Yard', 'Jimmy Japp', 'The other man', ' my\nfriend']]

quoteText: I fear you do not remember me, Inspector Japp.
subQuotationList: ['I fear you do not remember me, Inspector Japp.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
referringExpression: Poirot at once stepped forward and accosted the shorter of the two

quoteText:
Why, if it isn't Mr. Poirot! You've heard me speak of Mr. Poirot? It was in 1904 he and
I worked together   the Abercrombie forgery case   you remember, he was run
down in Brussels. Ah, those were great days, moosier. Then, do you
remember    Baron' Altara? There was a pretty rogue for you! He eluded
the clutches of half the police in Europe. But we nailed him in
Antwerp   thanks to Mr. Poirot here.
subQuotationList:
["Why, if it isn't Mr. Poirot!", "You've heard me speak of Mr. Poirot? It was in 1904 he and
I worked together   the Abercrombie forgery case   you remember, he was run
down in Brussels. Ah, those were great days, moosier. Then, do you
remember    Baron' Altara? There was a pretty rogue for you! He eluded
the clutches of half the police in Europe. But we nailed him in
Antwerp   thanks to Mr. Poirot here."]
speaker: Japp
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot']], [['Summerhaye'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Summerhaye'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Summerhaye'], ['Summerhaye'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Japp', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText: I need hardly ask what you are doing here, gentlemen,
subQuotationList: ['I need hardly ask what you are doing here, gentlemen,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, indeed. Pretty clear case I should say.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed. Pretty clear case I should say.']
speaker: Japp

quoteText: There I differ from you.
subQuotationList: ['There I differ from you.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Oh, come! Surely the whole thing is clear as daylight. The man's caught
red-handed. How he could be such a fool beats me!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, come!', "Surely the whole thing is clear as daylight. The man's caught\nred-handed. How he could be such a fool beats me!"]
speaker: Summerhaye

quoteText:
Hold your fire, Summerhaye, Me and Moosier
here have met before   and there's no man's judgment I'd sooner take than
his. If I'm not greatly mistaken, he's got something up his sleeve.
Isn't that so, moosier?
subQuotationList:
['Hold your fire, Summerhaye,', "Me and Moosier
here have met before   and there's no man's judgment I'd sooner take than
his. If I'm not greatly mistaken, he's got something up his sleeve.
Isn't that so, moosier?"]
speaker: Japp

quoteText: I have drawn certain conclusions   yes.
subQuotationList: ['I have drawn certain conclusions   yes.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
It's this way, so far, we've only seen the case from the
outside. That's where the Yard's at a disadvantage in a case of this
kind, where the murder's only out, so to speak, after the inquest. A
lot depends on being on the spot first thing, and that's where Mr.
Poirot's had the start of us. We shouldn't have been here as soon as
this even, if it hadn't been for the fact that there was a smart doctor
on the spot, who gave us the tip through the Coroner. But you've been
on the spot from the first, and you may have picked up some little
hints. From the evidence at the inquest, Mr. Inglethorp murdered his
wife as sure as I stand here, and if anyone but you hinted the contrary
I'd laugh in his face. I must say I was surprised the jury didn't bring
it in Wilful Murder against him right off. I think they would have, if
it hadn't been for the Coroner   he seemed to be holding them back.
subQuotationList:
["It's this way,", "so far, we've only seen the case from the
outside. That's where the Yard's at a disadvantage in a case of this
kind, where the murder's only out, so to speak, after the inquest. A
lot depends on being on the spot first thing, and that's where Mr.
Poirot's had the start of us. We shouldn't have been here as soon as
this even, if it hadn't been for the fact that there was a smart doctor
on the spot, who gave us the tip through the Coroner. But you've been
on the spot from the first, and you may have picked up some little
hints. From the evidence at the inquest, Mr. Inglethorp murdered his
wife as sure as I stand here, and if anyone but you hinted the contrary
I'd laugh in his face. I must say I was surprised the jury didn't bring
it in Wilful Murder against him right off. I think they would have, if
it hadn't been for the Coroner   he seemed to be holding them back."]
speaker: Japp
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Japp', 'Summerhaye'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Japp', 'Summerhaye'], ['Japp', 'Summerhaye'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Japp', 'Summerhaye'], ['Mr. Wells'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Wells'], ['Mr. Wells']]]

quoteText:
Perhaps, though, you have a warrant for his arrest in your pocket
now,
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps, though, you have a warrant for his arrest in your pocket\nnow,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Perhaps I have, and perhaps I haven't,
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps I have, and perhaps I haven't,"]
speaker: Japp

quoteText: I am very anxious, Messieurs, that he should not be arrested.
subQuotationList: ['I am very anxious, Messieurs, that he should not be arrested.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I dare say,
subQuotationList: ['I dare say,']
speaker: Summerhaye

quoteText:
Can't you go a little further, Mr. Poirot? A wink's as good as a
nod   from you. You've been on the spot   and the Yard doesn't want to make
any mistakes, you know.
subQuotationList: ["Can't you go a little further, Mr. Poirot? A wink's as good as a\nnod   from you. You've been on the spot   and the Yard doesn't want to make\nany mistakes, you know."]
speaker: Japp

quoteText:
That is exactly what I thought. Well, I will tell you this. Use your
warrant: Arrest Mr. Inglethorp. But it will bring you no kudos   the case
against him will be dismissed at once! _Comme   a!_
subQuotationList: ['That is exactly what I thought. Well, I will tell you this. Use your\nwarrant: Arrest Mr. Inglethorp. But it will bring you no kudos   the case\nagainst him will be dismissed at once! _Comme   a!_']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I daren't do it, Mr. Poirot. _I_'d take your word, but there's others
over me who'll be asking what the devil I mean by it. Can't you give me
a little more to go on?
subQuotationList: ["I daren't do it, Mr. Poirot. _I_'d take your word, but there's others\nover me who'll be asking what the devil I mean by it. Can't you give me\na little more to go on?"]
speaker: Japp

quoteText:
It can be done, I admit I do not wish it. It forces
my hand. I would have preferred to work in the dark just for the
present, but what you say is very just   the word of a Belgian policeman,
whose day is past, is not enough! And Alfred Inglethorp must not be
arrested. That I have sworn, as my friend Hastings here knows. See,
then, my good Japp, you go at once to Styles?
subQuotationList:
['It can be done,', 'I admit I do not wish it. It forces
my hand. I would have preferred to work in the dark just for the
present, but what you say is very just   the word of a Belgian policeman,
whose day is past, is not enough! And Alfred Inglethorp must not be
arrested. That I have sworn, as my friend Hastings here knows. See,
then, my good Japp, you go at once to Styles?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionTextsList: [[], ['you', 'a Belgian policeman,\nwhose day is past', 'Alfred Inglethorp', 'my friend Hastings', 'my good Japp', 'Japp', 'you']]

quoteText:
Well, in about half an hour. We're seeing the Coroner and the doctor
first.
subQuotationList: ["Well, in about half an hour. We're seeing the Coroner and the doctor\nfirst."]
speaker: Japp

quoteText:
Good. Call for me in passing   the last house in the village. I will go
with you. At Styles, Mr. Inglethorp will give you, or if he refuses   as
is probable   I will give you such proofs that shall satisfy you that the
case against him could not possibly be sustained. Is that a bargain?
subQuotationList:
['Good. Call for me in passing   the last house in the village. I will go
with you. At Styles, Mr. Inglethorp will give you, or if he refuses   as
is probable   I will give you such proofs that shall satisfy you that the
case against him could not possibly be sustained. Is that a bargain?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
That's a bargain, And, on behalf of the Yard,
I'm much obliged to you, though I'm bound to confess I can't at present
see the faintest possible loop-hole in the evidence, but you always
were a marvel! So long, then, moosier.
subQuotationList:
["That's a bargain,", "And, on behalf of the Yard,
I'm much obliged to you, though I'm bound to confess I can't at present
see the faintest possible loop-hole in the evidence, but you always
were a marvel! So long, then, moosier."]
speaker: Japp

quoteText:
Well, my friend, what do
you think? _Mon Dieu!_ I had some warm moments in that court; I did not
figure to myself that the man would be so pig-headed as to refuse to
say anything at all. Decidedly, it was the policy of an imbecile.
subQuotationList:
['Well, my friend,', 'what do
you think? _Mon Dieu!_ I had some warm moments in that court; I did not
figure to myself that the man would be so pig-headed as to refuse to
say anything at all. Decidedly, it was the policy of an imbecile.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
H'm! There are other explanations besides that of imbecility, For, if the case against him is true, how could he defend
himself except by silence?
subQuotationList: ["H'm! There are other explanations besides that of imbecility,", 'For, if the case against him is true, how could he defend\nhimself except by silence?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Why, in a thousand ingenious ways, See; say that it is
I who have committed this murder, I can think of seven most plausible
stories! Far more convincing than Mr. Inglethorp's stony denials!
subQuotationList: ['Why, in a thousand ingenious ways,', "See; say that it is\nI who have committed this murder, I can think of seven most plausible\nstories! Far more convincing than Mr. Inglethorp's stony denials!"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
My dear Poirot, I am sure you are capable of thinking of seventy! But,
seriously, in spite of what I heard you say to the detectives, you
surely cannot still believe in the possibility of Alfred Inglethorp's
innocence?
subQuotationList:
["My dear Poirot, I am sure you are capable of thinking of seventy! But,
seriously, in spite of what I heard you say to the detectives, you
surely cannot still believe in the possibility of Alfred Inglethorp's
innocence?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Why not now as much as before? Nothing has changed.
subQuotationList: ['Why not now as much as before? Nothing has changed.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But the evidence is so conclusive.
subQuotationList: ['But the evidence is so conclusive.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes, too conclusive.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, too conclusive.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, yes, too conclusive, Real
evidence is usually vague and unsatisfactory. It has to be
examined   sifted. But here the whole thing is cut and dried. No, my
friend, this evidence has been very cleverly manufactured   so cleverly
that it has defeated its own ends.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, yes, too conclusive,', 'Real
evidence is usually vague and unsatisfactory. It has to be
examined   sifted. But here the whole thing is cut and dried. No, my
friend, this evidence has been very cleverly manufactured   so cleverly
that it has defeated its own ends.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: How do you make that out?
subQuotationList: ['How do you make that out?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Because, so long as the evidence against him was vague and intangible,
it was very hard to disprove. But, in his anxiety, the criminal has
drawn the net so closely that one cut will set Inglethorp free.
subQuotationList: ['Because, so long as the evidence against him was vague and intangible,\nit was very hard to disprove. But, in his anxiety, the criminal has\ndrawn the net so closely that one cut will set Inglethorp free.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Let us look at the matter like this. Here is a man, let us say, who
sets out to poison his wife. He has lived by his wits as the saying
goes. Presumably, therefore, he has some wits. He is not altogether a
fool. Well, how does he set about it? He goes boldly to the village
chemist's and purchases strychnine under his own name, with a trumped
up story about a dog which is bound to be proved absurd. He does not
employ the poison that night. No, he waits until he has had a violent
quarrel with her, of which the whole household is cognisant, and which
naturally directs their suspicions upon him. He prepares no defence   no
shadow of an alibi, yet he knows the chemist's assistant must
necessarily come forward with the facts. Bah! Do not ask me to believe
that any man could be so idiotic! Only a lunatic, who wished to commit
suicide by causing himself to be hanged, would act so!
subQuotationList:
["Let us look at the matter like this. Here is a man, let us say, who
sets out to poison his wife. He has lived by his wits as the saying
goes. Presumably, therefore, he has some wits. He is not altogether a
fool. Well, how does he set about it? He goes boldly to the village
chemist's and purchases strychnine under his own name, with a trumped
up story about a dog which is bound to be proved absurd. He does not
employ the poison that night. No, he waits until he has had a violent
quarrel with her, of which the whole household is cognisant, and which
naturally directs their suspicions upon him. He prepares no defence   no
shadow of an alibi, yet he knows the chemist's assistant must
necessarily come forward with the facts. Bah! Do not ask me to believe
that any man could be so idiotic! Only a lunatic, who wished to commit
suicide by causing himself to be hanged, would act so!"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Still   I do not see

quoteText:
Neither do I see. I tell you, _mon ami_, it puzzles me. _Me_   Hercule
Poirot!
subQuotationList: ['Neither do I see. I tell you, _mon ami_, it puzzles me. _Me_   Hercule\nPoirot!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
But if you believe him innocent, how do you explain his buying the
strychnine?
subQuotationList: ['But if you believe him innocent, how do you explain his buying the\nstrychnine?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Very simply. He did _not_ buy it.
subQuotationList: ['Very simply. He did _not_ buy it.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But Mace recognized him!
subQuotationList: ['But Mace recognized him!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, he saw a man with a black beard like Mr.
Inglethorp's, and wearing glasses like Mr. Inglethorp, and dressed in
Mr. Inglethorp's rather noticeable clothes. He could not recognize a
man whom he had probably only seen in the distance, since, you
remember, he himself had only been in the village a fortnight, and Mrs.
Inglethorp dealt principally with Coot's in Tadminster.
subQuotationList:
["I beg your pardon, he saw a man with a black beard like Mr.

[['your', 'he', 'Mr.

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Mace'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Mace'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Mace'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: Then you think
subQuotationList: ['Then you think']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
_Mon ami_, do you remember the two points I laid stress upon? Leave
the first one for the moment, what was the second?
subQuotationList: ['_Mon ami_, do you remember the two points I laid stress upon? Leave\nthe first one for the moment, what was the second?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Exactly. Now suppose anyone wished to pass himself off as John or
Lawrence Cavendish. Would it be easy?
subQuotationList: ['Exactly. Now suppose anyone wished to pass himself off as John or\nLawrence Cavendish. Would it be easy?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, Of course an actor
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'Of course an actor']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
And why would it not be easy? I will tell you, my friend: Because they
are both clean-shaven men. To make up successfully as one of these two
in broad daylight, it would need an actor of genius, and a certain
initial facial resemblance. But in the case of Alfred Inglethorp, all
that is changed. His clothes, his beard, the glasses which hide his
eyes   those are the salient points about his personal appearance. Now,
what is the first instinct of the criminal? To divert suspicion from
himself, is it not so? And how can he best do that? By throwing it on
someone else. In this instance, there was a man ready to his hand.
Everybody was predisposed to believe in Mr. Inglethorp's guilt. It was
a foregone conclusion that he would be suspected; but, to make it a
sure thing there must be tangible proof   such as the actual buying of
the poison, and that, with a man of the peculiar appearance of Mr.
Inglethorp, was not difficult. Remember, this young Mace had never
actually spoken to Mr. Inglethorp. How should he doubt that the man in
his clothes, with his beard and his glasses, was not Alfred
Inglethorp?
subQuotationList:
["And why would it not be easy? I will tell you, my friend: Because they
are both clean-shaven men. To make up successfully as one of these two
in broad daylight, it would need an actor of genius, and a certain

that is changed. His clothes, his beard, the glasses which hide his

actually spoken to Mr. Inglethorp. How should he doubt that the man in

Inglethorp?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
