quoteText:
It may be so, But, if that
was the case, why does he not say where he was at six o'clock on Monday
evening?
subQuotationList: ['It may be so,', "But, if that\nwas the case, why does he not say where he was at six o'clock on Monday\nevening?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Ah, why indeed? If he were arrested, he
probably would speak, but I do not want it to come to that. I must make
him see the gravity of his position. There is, of course, something
discreditable behind his silence. If he did not murder his wife, he is,
nevertheless, a scoundrel, and has something of his own to conceal,
quite apart from the murder.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, why indeed?', 'If he were arrested, he
probably would speak, but I do not want it to come to that. I must make
him see the gravity of his position. There is, of course, something
discreditable behind his silence. If he did not murder his wife, he is,
nevertheless, a scoundrel, and has something of his own to conceal,
quite apart from the murder.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: What can it be?
subQuotationList: ['What can it be?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Can you not guess?
subQuotationList: ['Can you not guess?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, can you?
subQuotationList: ['No, can you?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, yes, I had a little idea sometime ago   and it has turned out to be
correct.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, I had a little idea sometime ago   and it has turned out to be\ncorrect.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You never told me,
subQuotationList: ['You never told me,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Pardon me, _mon ami_, you were not precisely _sympathique_.
subQuotationList: ['Pardon me, _mon ami_, you were not precisely _sympathique_.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Tell me   you see now that he must not be arrested?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me   you see now that he must not be arrested?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Perhaps,
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Come, my friend, apart from Mr.
Inglethorp, how did the evidence at the inquest strike you?
subQuotationList: ['Come, my friend,', 'apart from Mr.\nInglethorp, how did the evidence at the inquest strike you?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, pretty much what I expected.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, pretty much what I expected.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Did nothing strike you as peculiar about it?
subQuotationList: ['Did nothing strike you as peculiar about it?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: In what way?
subQuotationList: ['In what way?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Well, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish's evidence for instance?
subQuotationList: ["Well, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish's evidence for instance?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, Lawrence! No, I don't think so. He's always a nervous chap.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, Lawrence! No, I don't think so. He's always a nervous chap."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
His suggestion that his mother might have been poisoned accidentally
by means of the tonic she was taking, that did not strike you as
strange    _hein?_
subQuotationList: ['His suggestion that his mother might have been poisoned accidentally\nby means of the tonic she was taking, that did not strike you as\nstrange    _hein?_']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
No, I can't say it did. The doctors ridiculed it of course. But it was
quite a natural suggestion for a layman to make.
subQuotationList: ["No, I can't say it did. The doctors ridiculed it of course. But it was\nquite a natural suggestion for a layman to make."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
But Monsieur Lawrence is not a layman. You told me yourself that he
had started by studying medicine, and that he had taken his degree.
subQuotationList: ['But Monsieur Lawrence is not a layman. You told me yourself that he\nhad started by studying medicine, and that he had taken his degree.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText: Yes, that's true. I never thought of that.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's true. I never thought of that."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
It
_is_ odd.
subQuotationList: ['It\n_is_ odd.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
From the first, his behaviour has been peculiar. Of all the household,
he alone would be likely to recognize the symptoms of strychnine
poisoning, and yet we find him the only member of the family to uphold
strenuously the theory of death from natural causes. If it had been
Monsieur John, I could have understood it. He has no technical
knowledge, and is by nature unimaginative. But Monsieur Lawrence   no!
And now, to-day, he puts forward a suggestion that he himself must have
known was ridiculous. There is food for thought in this, _mon ami!_
subQuotationList:
['From the first, his behaviour has been peculiar. Of all the household,
he alone would be likely to recognize the symptoms of strychnine
poisoning, and yet we find him the only member of the family to uphold
strenuously the theory of death from natural causes. If it had been
Monsieur John, I could have understood it. He has no technical
knowledge, and is by nature unimaginative. But Monsieur Lawrence   no!
And now, to-day, he puts forward a suggestion that he himself must have
known was ridiculous. There is food for thought in this, _mon ami!_']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Evelyn Howard', 'John Cavendish', 'Manning', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Annie', 'Dorcas'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: It's very confusing,
subQuotationList: ["It's very confusing,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Then there is Mrs. Cavendish, That's another who
is not telling all she knows! What do you make of her attitude?
subQuotationList: ['Then there is Mrs. Cavendish,', "That's another who\nis not telling all she knows! What do you make of her attitude?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I don't know what to make of it. It seems inconceivable that she
should be shielding Alfred Inglethorp. Yet that is what it looks like.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know what to make of it. It seems inconceivable that she\nshould be shielding Alfred Inglethorp. Yet that is what it looks like."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Yes, it is queer. One thing is certain, she overheard a good deal more
of that
subQuotationList: ['Yes, it is queer. One thing is certain, she overheard a good deal more\nof that']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: than she was willing to admit.
subQuotationList: ['than she was willing to admit.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
And yet she is the last person one would accuse of stooping to
eavesdrop!
subQuotationList: ['And yet she is the last person one would accuse of stooping to\neavesdrop!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Exactly. One thing her evidence _has_ shown me. I made a mistake.
Dorcas was quite right. The quarrel did take place earlier in the
afternoon, about four o'clock, as she said.
subQuotationList: ["Exactly. One thing her evidence _has_ shown me. I made a mistake.\nDorcas was quite right. The quarrel did take place earlier in the\nafternoon, about four o'clock, as she said."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, a good deal that was peculiar came out to-day, Dr. Bauerstein, now, what was _he_ doing up and dressed at that hour
in the morning? It is astonishing to me that no one commented on the
fact.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, a good deal that was peculiar came out to-day,', 'Dr. Bauerstein, now, what was _he_ doing up and dressed at that hour\nin the morning? It is astonishing to me that no one commented on the\nfact.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: He has insomnia, I believe,
subQuotationList: ['He has insomnia, I believe,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Which is a very good, or a very bad explanation, It
covers everything, and explains nothing. I shall keep my eye on our
clever Dr. Bauerstein.
subQuotationList: ['Which is a very good, or a very bad explanation,', 'It\ncovers everything, and explains nothing. I shall keep my eye on our\nclever Dr. Bauerstein.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Any more faults to find with the evidence?
subQuotationList: ['Any more faults to find with the evidence?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
_Mon ami_, when you find that people are not
telling you the truth   look out! Now, unless I am much mistaken, at the
inquest to-day only one   at most, two persons were speaking the truth
without reservation or subterfuge.
subQuotationList:
['_Mon ami_,', 'when you find that people are not
telling you the truth   look out! Now, unless I am much mistaken, at the
inquest to-day only one   at most, two persons were speaking the truth
without reservation or subterfuge.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Oh, come now, Poirot! I won't cite Lawrence, or Mrs. Cavendish. But
there's John   and Miss Howard, surely they were speaking the truth?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, come now, Poirot! I won't cite Lawrence, or Mrs. Cavendish. But\nthere's John   and Miss Howard, surely they were speaking the truth?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['John Cavendish', 'Evelyn Howard']]]

quoteText: Both of them, my friend? One, I grant you, but both      !
subQuotationList: ['Both of them, my friend? One, I grant you, but both      !']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Do you really think so? Miss Howard had always seemed to me
so essentially honest   almost uncomfortably so.
subQuotationList: ['Do you really think so?', 'Miss Howard had always seemed to me\nso essentially honest   almost uncomfortably so.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Miss Murdoch too, there's nothing untruthful about
_her_.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Murdoch too,', "there's nothing untruthful about\n_her_."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No. But it was strange that she never heard a sound, sleeping next
door; whereas Mrs. Cavendish, in the other wing of the building,
distinctly heard the table fall.
subQuotationList: ['No. But it was strange that she never heard a sound, sleeping next\ndoor; whereas Mrs. Cavendish, in the other wing of the building,\ndistinctly heard the table fall.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, she's young. And she sleeps soundly.
subQuotationList: ["Well, she's young. And she sleeps soundly."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Ah, yes, indeed! She must be a famous sleeper, that one!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, yes, indeed! She must be a famous sleeper, that one!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
_Mesdames_ and _messieurs_, I have asked you to come here
all together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred
Inglethorp.
subQuotationList: ['_Mesdames_ and _messieurs_,', 'I have asked you to come here\nall together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred\nInglethorp.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Mr. Inglethorp, a very dark
shadow is resting on this house   the shadow of murder.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Inglethorp,', 'a very dark\nshadow is resting on this house   the shadow of murder.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: My poor wife, Poor Emily! It is terrible.
subQuotationList: ['My poor wife,', 'Poor Emily! It is terrible.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp

quoteText:
I do not think, monsieur, that you quite
realize how terrible it may be   for you.

that you quite realize

No. I do not believe that anyone could be so monstrous as to accuse me
of what you say.
subQuotationList: ['No. I do not believe that anyone could be so monstrous as to accuse me\nof what you say.']

addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

subQuotationList: ['_Soit!_', 'Then I must speak for you.']

addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: You? How can you speak? You do not know
subQuotationList: ['You? How can you speak? You do not know']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
_Mesdames_ and _messieurs_! I speak! Listen!
I, Hercule Poirot, affirm that the man who entered the chemist's shop,
and purchased strychnine at six o'clock on Monday last was not Mr.
Inglethorp, for at six o'clock on that day Mr. Inglethorp was escorting
Mrs. Raikes back to her home from a neighbouring farm. I can produce no
less than five witnesses to swear to having seen them together, either
at six or just after and, as you may know, the Abbey Farm, Mrs.
Raikes's home, is at least two and a half miles distant from the
village. There is absolutely no question as to the alibi!
subQuotationList:
["_Mesdames_ and _messieurs_! I speak! Listen!
I, Hercule Poirot, affirm that the man who entered the chemist's shop,
and purchased strychnine at six o'clock on Monday last was not Mr.
Inglethorp, for at six o'clock on that day Mr. Inglethorp was escorting
Mrs. Raikes back to her home from a neighbouring farm. I can produce no
less than five witnesses to swear to having seen them together, either
at six or just after and, as you may know, the Abbey Farm, Mrs.
Raikes's home, is at least two and a half miles distant from the
village. There is absolutely no question as to the alibi!"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText:
My word, you're the goods! And no mistake, Mr. Poirot!
These witnesses of yours are all right, I suppose?
subQuotationList: ['My word,', "you're the goods! And no mistake, Mr. Poirot!\nThese witnesses of yours are all right, I suppose?"]

addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
_Voil  !_ I have prepared a list of them   names and addresses. You must
see them, of course. But you will find it all right.
subQuotationList: ['_Voil  !_ I have prepared a list of them   names and addresses. You must\nsee them, of course. But you will find it all right.']

addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Summerhaye']

I'm much obliged to you. A
pretty mare's nest arresting him would have been.

But, if you'll excuse me, sir, why couldn't you say all
this at the inquest?
subQuotationList: ["But, if you'll excuse me, sir, why couldn't you say all\nthis at the inquest?"]

addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

I will tell you why, There was a certain
rumour
subQuotationList: ['I will tell you why,', 'There was a certain\nrumour']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: A most malicious and utterly untrue one,
subQuotationList: ['A most malicious and utterly untrue one,']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
And Mr. Inglethorp was anxious to have no scandal revived just at
present. Am I right?
subQuotationList: ['And Mr. Inglethorp was anxious to have no scandal revived just at\npresent. Am I right?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Summerhaye']

quoteText: Quite right.
subQuotationList: ['Quite right.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
With my poor Emily not yet buried,
can you wonder I was anxious that no more lying rumours should be
started.
subQuotationList: ['With my poor Emily not yet buried,\ncan you wonder I was anxious that no more lying rumours should be\nstarted.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
Between you and me, sir, I'd sooner have any amount
of rumours than be arrested for murder. And I venture to think your
poor lady would have felt the same. And, if it hadn't been for Mr.
Poirot here, arrested you would have been, as sure as eggs is eggs!
subQuotationList:
['Between you and me, sir,', "I'd sooner have any amount
of rumours than be arrested for murder. And I venture to think your
poor lady would have felt the same. And, if it hadn't been for Mr.
Poirot here, arrested you would have been, as sure as eggs is eggs!"]
speaker: Japp
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText:
I was foolish, no doubt, But you do not know,
inspector, how I have been persecuted and maligned.
subQuotationList: ['I was foolish, no doubt,', 'But you do not know,\ninspector, how I have been persecuted and maligned.']
speaker: Mr. Inglethorp

Now, sir, I should like to see

show me the way.

quoteText:
Quick, go to the other wing. Stand there   just this side of the baize
door. Do not move till I come.
subQuotationList: ['Quick, go to the other wing. Stand there   just this side of the baize\ndoor. Do not move till I come.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You have not stirred?
subQuotationList: ['You have not stirred?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, I've stuck here like a rock. Nothing's happened.
subQuotationList: ["No, I've stuck here like a rock. Nothing's happened."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You've seen nothing at all?
subQuotationList: ["You've seen nothing at all?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: But you have probably heard something? A big bump   eh, _mon ami?_
subQuotationList: ['But you have probably heard something? A big bump   eh, _mon ami?_']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Is it possible? Ah, but I am vexed with myself! I am not usually
clumsy. I made but a slight gesture
subQuotationList: ['Is it possible? Ah, but I am vexed with myself! I am not usually\nclumsy. I made but a slight gesture']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
with the
left hand, and over went the table by the bed!
subQuotationList: ['with the\nleft hand, and over went the table by the bed!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Never mind, old chap. What does it matter? Your triumph downstairs
excited you. I can tell you, that was a surprise to us all. There must
be more in this affair of Inglethorp's with Mrs. Raikes than we
thought, to make him hold his tongue so persistently. What are you
going to do now? Where are the Scotland Yard fellows?
subQuotationList:
["Never mind, old chap. What does it matter? Your triumph downstairs
excited you. I can tell you, that was a surprise to us all. There must
be more in this affair of Inglethorp's with Mrs. Raikes than we

speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Japp', 'Summerhaye']]]

quoteText:
Gone down to interview the servants. I showed them all our exhibits. I
am disappointed in Japp. He has no method!
subQuotationList: ['Gone down to interview the servants. I showed them all our exhibits. I\nam disappointed in Japp. He has no method!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Hullo! Here's Dr. Bauerstein. I
believe you're right about that man, Poirot. I don't like him.
subQuotationList: ['Hullo!', "Here's Dr. Bauerstein. I\nbelieve you're right about that man, Poirot. I don't like him."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: He is clever,
subQuotationList: ['He is clever,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Oh, clever as the devil! I must say I was overjoyed to see him in the
plight he was in on Tuesday. You never saw such a spectacle!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, clever as the devil! I must say I was overjoyed to see him in the\nplight he was in on Tuesday. You never saw such a spectacle!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
He looked a regular scarecrow!
Plastered with mud from head to foot.
subQuotationList: ['He looked a regular scarecrow!\nPlastered with mud from head to foot.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: You saw him, then?
subQuotationList: ['You saw him, then?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes. Of course, he didn't want to come in   it was just after dinner   but
Mr. Inglethorp insisted.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. Of course, he didn't want to come in   it was just after dinner   but\nMr. Inglethorp insisted."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Was Dr.
Bauerstein here on Tuesday evening? Here? And you never told me? Why
did you not tell me? Why? Why?
subQuotationList: ['Was Dr.\nBauerstein here on Tuesday evening? Here? And you never told me? Why\ndid you not tell me? Why? Why?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
My dear Poirot, I never thought it would interest
you. I didn't know it was of any importance.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Poirot,', "I never thought it would interest\nyou. I didn't know it was of any importance."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Importance? It is of the first importance! So Dr. Bauerstein was here
on Tuesday night   the night of the murder. Hastings, do you not see?
That alters everything   everything!
subQuotationList: ['Importance? It is of the first importance! So Dr. Bauerstein was here\non Tuesday night   the night of the murder. Hastings, do you not see?\nThat alters everything   everything!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, that alters everything   everything.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that alters everything   everything.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
referringExpression: he mechanically straightened a pair of candlesticks still murmuring to himself

quoteText: _Allons!_ We must act at once. Where is Mr. Cavendish?
subQuotationList: ['_Allons!_', 'We must act at once. Where is Mr. Cavendish?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Mr. Cavendish, I have some important business in Tadminster. A new
clue. May I take your motor?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Cavendish, I have some important business in Tadminster. A new\nclue. May I take your motor?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Why, of course. Do you mean at once?
subQuotationList: ['Why, of course. Do you mean at once?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: If you please.
subQuotationList: ['If you please.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Now, Poirot, perhaps you will tell me what
all this is about?
subQuotationList: ['Now, Poirot,', 'perhaps you will tell me what\nall this is about?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Well, _mon ami_, a good deal you can guess for yourself. Of course you
realize that, now Mr. Inglethorp is out of it, the whole position is
greatly changed. We are face to face with an entirely new problem. We
know now that there is one person who did not buy the poison. We have
cleared away the manufactured clues. Now for the real ones. I have
ascertained that anyone in the household, with the exception of Mrs.
Cavendish, who was playing tennis with you, could have personated Mr.
Inglethorp on Monday evening. In the same way, we have his statement
that he put the coffee down in the hall. No one took much notice of
that at the inquest   but now it has a very different significance. We
must find out who did take that coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp eventually,
or who passed through the hall whilst it was standing there. From your
account, there are only two people whom we can positively say did not
go near the coffee   Mrs. Cavendish, and Mademoiselle Cynthia.
subQuotationList:
['Well, _mon ami_, a good deal you can guess for yourself. Of course you
realize that, now Mr. Inglethorp is out of it, the whole position is
greatly changed. We are face to face with an entirely new problem. We
know now that there is one person who did not buy the poison. We have
cleared away the manufactured clues. Now for the real ones. I have
ascertained that anyone in the household, with the exception of Mrs.
Cavendish, who was playing tennis with you, could have personated Mr.
Inglethorp on Monday evening. In the same way, we have his statement
that he put the coffee down in the hall. No one took much notice of
that at the inquest   but now it has a very different significance. We
must find out who did take that coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp eventually,
or who passed through the hall whilst it was standing there. From your
account, there are only two people whom we can positively say did not
go near the coffee   Mrs. Cavendish, and Mademoiselle Cynthia.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Miss Murdoch']]]

quoteText: Yes, that is so.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that is so.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
In clearing Alfred Inglethorp, I have been obliged
to show my hand sooner than I intended. As long as I might be thought
to be pursuing him, the criminal would be off his guard. Now, he will
be doubly careful. Yes   doubly careful. Tell
me, Hastings, you yourself   have you no suspicions of anybody?
subQuotationList:
['In clearing Alfred Inglethorp,', 'I have been obliged
to show my hand sooner than I intended. As long as I might be thought
to be pursuing him, the criminal would be off his guard. Now, he will
be doubly careful. Yes   doubly careful.', 'Tell
me, Hastings, you yourself   have you no suspicions of anybody?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
You couldn't call it a suspicion, It's so utterly
foolish.
subQuotationList: ["You couldn't call it a suspicion,", "It's so utterly\nfoolish."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Come now, Do not fear. Speak your mind.
You should always pay attention to your instincts.
subQuotationList: ['Come now,', 'Do not fear. Speak your mind.\nYou should always pay attention to your instincts.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Well then, it's absurd   but I suspect Miss Howard of
not telling all she knows!
subQuotationList: ['Well then,', "it's absurd   but I suspect Miss Howard of\nnot telling all she knows!"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Miss Howard?
subQuotationList: ['Miss Howard?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes   you'll laugh at me
subQuotationList: ["Yes   you'll laugh at me"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Not at all. Why should I?
subQuotationList: ['Not at all. Why should I?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
I can't help feeling, that we've rather
left her out of the possible suspects, simply on the strength of her
having been away from the place. But, after all, she was only fifteen
miles away. A car would do it in half an hour. Can we say positively
that she was away from Styles on the night of the murder?
subQuotationList:
["I can't help feeling,", "that we've rather
left her out of the possible suspects, simply on the strength of her
having been away from the place. But, after all, she was only fifteen
miles away. A car would do it in half an hour. Can we say positively
that she was away from Styles on the night of the murder?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Evelyn Howard']]]

quoteText:
Yes, my friend, we can. One of my first
actions was to ring up the hospital where she was working.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, my friend,', 'we can. One of my first\nactions was to ring up the hospital where she was working.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Well, I learnt that Miss Howard had been on afternoon duty on Tuesday,
and that   a convoy coming in unexpectedly   she had kindly offered to
remain on night duty, which offer was gratefully accepted. That
disposes of that.
subQuotationList:
['Well, I learnt that Miss Howard had been on afternoon duty on Tuesday,
and that   a convoy coming in unexpectedly   she had kindly offered to
remain on night duty, which offer was gratefully accepted. That
disposes of that.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Really, it's her
extraordinary vehemence against Inglethorp that started me off
suspecting her. I can't help feeling she'd do anything against him. And
I had an idea she might know something about the destroying of the
will. She might have burnt the new one, mistaking it for the earlier
one in his favour. She is so terribly bitter against him.
subQuotationList:
['Really,', "it's her
extraordinary vehemence against Inglethorp that started me off
suspecting her. I can't help feeling she'd do anything against him. And
I had an idea she might know something about the destroying of the
will. She might have burnt the new one, mistaking it for the earlier
one in his favour. She is so terribly bitter against him."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText: You consider her vehemence unnatural?
subQuotationList: ['You consider her vehemence unnatural?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Y   es. She is so very violent. I wondered really whether she is quite
sane on that point.
subQuotationList: ['Y   es. She is so very violent. I wondered really whether she is quite\nsane on that point.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, no, you are on a wrong tack there. There is nothing weak-minded or
degenerate about Miss Howard. She is an excellent specimen of
well-balanced English beef and brawn. She is sanity itself.
subQuotationList: ['No, no, you are on a wrong tack there. There is nothing weak-minded or\ndegenerate about Miss Howard. She is an excellent specimen of\nwell-balanced English beef and brawn. She is sanity itself.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yet her hatred of Inglethorp seems almost a mania. My idea was   a very
ridiculous one, no doubt   that she had intended to poison him   and that,
in some way, Mrs. Inglethorp got hold of it by mistake. But I don't at
all see how it could have been done. The whole thing is absurd and
ridiculous to the last degree.
subQuotationList:
["Yet her hatred of Inglethorp seems almost a mania. My idea was   a very
ridiculous one, no doubt   that she had intended to poison him   and that,
in some way, Mrs. Inglethorp got hold of it by mistake. But I don't at
all see how it could have been done. The whole thing is absurd and
ridiculous to the last degree."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Still you are right in one thing. It is always wise to suspect
everybody until you can prove logically, and to your own satisfaction,
that they are innocent. Now, what reasons are there against Miss
Howard's having deliberately poisoned Mrs. Inglethorp?
subQuotationList:
["Still you are right in one thing. It is always wise to suspect
everybody until you can prove logically, and to your own satisfaction,
that they are innocent. Now, what reasons are there against Miss
Howard's having deliberately poisoned Mrs. Inglethorp?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Why, she was devoted to her!
subQuotationList: ['Why, she was devoted to her!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Tcha! Tcha! You argue like a child. If Miss
Howard were capable of poisoning the old lady, she would be quite
equally capable of simulating devotion. No, we must look elsewhere. You
are perfectly correct in your assumption that her vehemence against
Alfred Inglethorp is too violent to be natural; but you are quite wrong
in the deduction you draw from it. I have drawn my own deductions,
which I believe to be correct, but I will not speak of them at
present.
subQuotationList:
['Tcha! Tcha!', 'You argue like a child. If Miss
Howard were capable of poisoning the old lady, she would be quite
equally capable of simulating devotion. No, we must look elsewhere. You
are perfectly correct in your assumption that her vehemence against
Alfred Inglethorp is too violent to be natural; but you are quite wrong
in the deduction you draw from it. I have drawn my own deductions,
which I believe to be correct, but I will not speak of them at
present.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Hastings'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText:
Now, to my way of
thinking, there is one insuperable objection to Miss Howard's being the
murderess.
subQuotationList: ["Now, to my way of\nthinking, there is one insuperable objection to Miss Howard's being the\nmurderess."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
referringExpression: He paused a minute then went on

quoteText: And that is?
subQuotationList: ['And that is?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
That in no possible way could Mrs. Inglethorp's death benefit Miss
Howard. Now there is no murder without a motive.
subQuotationList: ["That in no possible way could Mrs. Inglethorp's death benefit Miss\nHoward. Now there is no murder without a motive."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Could not Mrs. Inglethorp have made a will in her favour?
subQuotationList: ['Could not Mrs. Inglethorp have made a will in her favour?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: But you yourself suggested that possibility to Mr. Wells?
subQuotationList: ['But you yourself suggested that possibility to Mr. Wells?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
That was for a reason. I did not want to mention the name of the
person who was actually in my mind. Miss Howard occupied very much the
same position, so I used her name instead.
subQuotationList: ['That was for a reason. I did not want to mention the name of the\nperson who was actually in my mind. Miss Howard occupied very much the\nsame position, so I used her name instead.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Still, Mrs. Inglethorp might have done so. Why, that will, made on the
afternoon of her death may
subQuotationList: ['Still, Mrs. Inglethorp might have done so. Why, that will, made on the\nafternoon of her death may']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, my friend. I have certain little ideas of my own about that will.
But I can tell you this much   it was not in Miss Howard's favour.
subQuotationList: ["No, my friend. I have certain little ideas of my own about that will.\nBut I can tell you this much   it was not in Miss Howard's favour."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Well, we will acquit Miss Howard, then. It is
partly your fault that I ever came to suspect her. It was what you said
about her evidence at the inquest that set me off.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'we will acquit Miss Howard, then. It is\npartly your fault that I ever came to suspect her. It was what you said\nabout her evidence at the inquest that set me off.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Evelyn Howard']]]

quoteText: What did I say about her evidence at the inquest?
subQuotationList: ['What did I say about her evidence at the inquest?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Don't you remember? When I cited her and John Cavendish as being above
suspicion?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you remember? When I cited her and John Cavendish as being above\nsuspicion?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh   ah   yes.
subQuotationList: ['Oh   ah   yes.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
By
the way, Hastings, there is something I want you to do for me.
subQuotationList: ['By\nthe way, Hastings, there is something I want you to do for me.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Certainly. What is it?
subQuotationList: ['Certainly. What is it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Next time you happen to be alone with Lawrence Cavendish, I want you
to say this to him.    I have a message for you, from Poirot. He says:
subQuotationList: ['Next time you happen to be alone with Lawrence Cavendish, I want you\nto say this to him.    I have a message for you, from Poirot. He says:']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
' Nothing more.
Nothing less.
subQuotationList: ["' Nothing more.\nNothing less."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Is that
right?
subQuotationList: ['Is that\nright?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Excellent.
subQuotationList: ['Excellent.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But what does it mean?
subQuotationList: ['But what does it mean?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Ah, that I will leave you to find out. You have access to the facts.
Just say that to him, and see what he says.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, that I will leave you to find out. You have access to the facts.\nJust say that to him, and see what he says.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText: Very well   but it's all extremely mysterious.
subQuotationList: ["Very well   but it's all extremely mysterious."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: There, That is all my business.
subQuotationList: ['There,', 'That is all my business.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: What were you doing there?
subQuotationList: ['What were you doing there?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I left something to be analysed.
subQuotationList: ['I left something to be analysed.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes, but what?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but what?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: The sample of cocoa I took from the saucepan in the bedroom.
subQuotationList: ['The sample of cocoa I took from the saucepan in the bedroom.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
But that has already been tested! Dr. Bauerstein
had it tested, and you yourself laughed at the possibility of there
being strychnine in it.
subQuotationList: ['But that has already been tested!', 'Dr. Bauerstein\nhad it tested, and you yourself laughed at the possibility of there\nbeing strychnine in it.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I know Dr. Bauerstein had it tested,
subQuotationList: ['I know Dr. Bauerstein had it tested,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, then?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Well, I have a fancy for having it analysed again, that is all.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I have a fancy for having it analysed again, that is all.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
And really it's a great relief to think he's going, Hastings, It was bad enough before, when we thought
he'd done it, but I'm hanged if it isn't worse now, when we all feel
guilty for having been so down on the fellow. The fact is, we've
treated him abominably. Of course, things did look black against him. I
don't see how anyone could blame us for jumping to the conclusions we
did. Still, there it is, we were in the wrong, and now there's a
beastly feeling that one ought to make amends; which is difficult, when
one doesn't like the fellow a bit better than one did before. The whole
thing's damned awkward! And I'm thankful he's had the tact to take
himself off. It's a good thing Styles wasn't the mater's to leave to
him. Couldn't bear to think of the fellow lording it here. He's welcome
to her money.
subQuotationList:
["And really it's a great relief to think he's going, Hastings,", "It was bad enough before, when we thought
he'd done it, but I'm hanged if it isn't worse now, when we all feel
guilty for having been so down on the fellow. The fact is, we've
treated him abominably. Of course, things did look black against him. I
don't see how anyone could blame us for jumping to the conclusions we
did. Still, there it is, we were in the wrong, and now there's a
beastly feeling that one ought to make amends; which is difficult, when
one doesn't like the fellow a bit better than one did before. The whole
thing's damned awkward! And I'm thankful he's had the tact to take
himself off. It's a good thing Styles wasn't the mater's to leave to
him. Couldn't bear to think of the fellow lording it here. He's welcome
to her money."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: You'll be able to keep up the place all right?
subQuotationList: ["You'll be able to keep up the place all right?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, yes. There are the death duties, of course, but half my father's
money goes with the place, and Lawrence will stay with us for the
present, so there is his share as well. We shall be pinched at first,
of course, because, as I once told you, I am in a bit of a hole
financially myself. Still, the Johnnies will wait now.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, yes. There are the death duties, of course, but half my father's
money goes with the place, and Lawrence will stay with us for the
present, so there is his share as well. We shall be pinched at first,
of course, because, as I once told you, I am in a bit of a hole
financially myself. Still, the Johnnies will wait now."]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: Certainly. What is it, Dorcas?
subQuotationList: ['Certainly. What is it, Dorcas?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Well, it's just this, sir. You'll be seeing the Belgian gentleman
to-day perhaps?
subQuotationList: ["Well, it's just this, sir. You'll be seeing the Belgian gentleman\nto-day perhaps?"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Well, sir, you know how he asked me so
particular if the mistress, or anyone else, had a green dress?
subQuotationList: ['Well, sir, you know how he asked me so\nparticular if the mistress, or anyone else, had a green dress?']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Yes, yes. You have found one?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes. You have found one?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, not that, sir. But since then I've remembered what the young
gentlemen
subQuotationList: ["No, not that, sir. But since then I've remembered what the young\ngentlemen"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
call the    dressing-up box.' It's up in the front attic, sir. A
great chest, full of old clothes and fancy dresses, and what not. And
it came to me sudden like that there might be a green dress amongst
them. So, if you'd tell the Belgian gentleman
subQuotationList:
["call the    dressing-up box.' It's up in the front attic, sir. A
great chest, full of old clothes and fancy dresses, and what not. And
it came to me sudden like that there might be a green dress amongst

speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: I will tell him, Dorcas,
subQuotationList: ['I will tell him, Dorcas,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Thank you very much, sir. A very nice gentleman he is, sir. And quite
a different class from them two detectives from London, what goes
prying about, and asking questions. I don't hold with foreigners as a
rule, but from what the newspapers say I make out as how these brave
Belges isn't the ordinary run of foreigners, and certainly he's a most
polite spoken gentleman.
subQuotationList:
["Thank you very much, sir. A very nice gentleman he is, sir. And quite

quoteText:
Ah, the brave Dorcas! We will look at the chest, although   but no
matter   we will examine it all the same.

quoteText: Look!

quoteText: _Oh  !_ _Oh  !_

quoteText: New, Yes, quite new.
subQuotationList: ['New,', 'Yes, quite new.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
We have been looking through that chest, Dorcas. I am much obliged to
you for mentioning it. There is, indeed, a fine collection there. Are
they often used, may I ask?
subQuotationList: ['We have been looking through that chest, Dorcas. I am much obliged to\nyou for mentioning it. There is, indeed, a fine collection there. Are\nthey often used, may I ask?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
referringExpression: Poirot wished her good morning with Gallic politeness and went on

quoteText:
Well, sir, not very often nowadays, though from time to time we do
have what the young gentlemen call
subQuotationList: ['Well, sir, not very often nowadays, though from time to time we do\nhave what the young gentlemen call']

quoteText:
And very funny
it is sometimes, sir. Mr. Lawrence, he's wonderful. Most comic! I shall
never forget the night he came down as the Char of Persia, I think he
called it   a sort of Eastern King it was. He had the big paper knife in
his hand, and
subQuotationList:
["And very funny
it is sometimes, sir. Mr. Lawrence, he's wonderful. Most comic! I shall

quoteText: he says,
subQuotationList: ['he says,']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Miss Cynthia, she was
what they call an Apache, or some such name   a Frenchified sort of
cut-throat, I take it to be. A real sight she looked. You'd never have
believed a pretty young lady like that could have made herself into
such a ruffian. Nobody would have known her.
subQuotationList:
["Miss Cynthia, she was
what they call an Apache, or some such name   a Frenchified sort of
cut-throat, I take it to be. A real sight she looked. You'd never have
believed a pretty young lady like that could have made herself into
such a ruffian. Nobody would have known her."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
These evenings must have been great fun, I
suppose Mr. Lawrence wore that fine black beard in the chest upstairs,
when he was Shah of Persia?
subQuotationList: ['These evenings must have been great fun,', 'I\nsuppose Mr. Lawrence wore that fine black beard in the chest upstairs,\nwhen he was Shah of Persia?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
He did have a beard, sir, And well I know
it, for he borrowed two skeins of my black wool to make it with! And
I'm sure it looked wonderfully natural at a distance. I didn't know as
there was a beard up there at all. It must have been got quite lately,
I think. There was a red wig, I know, but nothing else in the way of
hair. Burnt corks they use mostly   though    tis messy getting it off
again. Miss Cynthia was a nigger once, and, oh, the trouble she had.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: No.

quoteText:
Yes. It was cut exactly the shape of Mr. Inglethorp's, and I found one
or two snipped hairs. Hastings, this affair is very deep.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. It was cut exactly the shape of Mr. Inglethorp's, and I found one\nor two snipped hairs. Hastings, this affair is very deep."]

subQuotationList: ['Who put it in the chest, I wonder?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Someone with a good deal of intelligence, You
realize that he chose the one place in the house to hide it where its
presence would not be remarked? Yes, he is intelligent. But we must be
more intelligent. We must be so intelligent that he does not suspect us
of being intelligent at all.
subQuotationList:
['Someone with a good deal of intelligence,', 'You
realize that he chose the one place in the house to hide it where its

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: There, _mon ami_, you will be of great assistance to me.
subQuotationList: ['There, _mon ami_, you will be of great assistance to me.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, you will be
invaluable.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'you will be\ninvaluable.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I must have an ally in the house,
subQuotationList: ['I must have an ally in the house,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You have me,
subQuotationList: ['You have me,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: True, but you are not sufficient.

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
You do not quite take my meaning. You are known to be working with me.
I want somebody who is not associated with us in any way.
subQuotationList: ['You do not quite take my meaning. You are known to be working with me.\nI want somebody who is not associated with us in any way.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, I think not.
subQuotationList: ['No, I think not.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: The dear fellow isn't perhaps very bright,
subQuotationList: ["The dear fellow isn't perhaps very bright,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Here comes Miss Howard, She is the very
person. But I am in her black books, since I cleared Mr. Inglethorp.
Still, we can but try.

Well, Monsieur Poirot, what is it? Out
with it. I'm busy.
subQuotationList: ['Well, Monsieur Poirot,', "what is it? Out\nwith it. I'm busy."]

quoteText: Do you remember, mademoiselle, that I once asked you to help me?

quoteText:
And I told you I'd help you with
pleasure   to hang Alfred Inglethorp.
subQuotationList: ["And I told you I'd help you with\npleasure   to hang Alfred Inglethorp."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Miss Howard, I will ask you one
question. I beg of you to reply to it truthfully.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Howard, I will ask you one\nquestion. I beg of you to reply to it truthfully.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Never tell lies,
subQuotationList: ['Never tell lies,']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
It is this. Do you still believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by
her husband?
subQuotationList: ['It is this. Do you still believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by\nher husband?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
What do you mean? You needn't think your pretty
explanations influence me in the slightest. I'll admit that it wasn't
he who bought strychnine at the chemist's shop. What of that? I dare
say he soaked fly paper, as I told you at the beginning.
subQuotationList:
['What do you mean?', "You needn't think your pretty
explanations influence me in the slightest. I'll admit that it wasn't
he who bought strychnine at the chemist's shop. What of that? I dare

speaker: Evelyn Howard
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot']], [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText: That is arsenic   not strychnine,
subQuotationList: ['That is arsenic   not strychnine,']

quoteText:
What does that matter? Arsenic would put poor Emily out of the way
just as well as strychnine. If I'm convinced he did it, it doesn't
matter a jot to me _how_ he did it.
subQuotationList: ["What does that matter? Arsenic would put poor Emily out of the way\njust as well as strychnine. If I'm convinced he did it, it doesn't\nmatter a jot to me _how_ he did it."]
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
Exactly. _If_ you are convinced he did it, I
will put my question in another form. Did you ever in your heart of
hearts believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by her husband?
subQuotationList: ['Exactly. _If_ you are convinced he did it,', 'I\nwill put my question in another form. Did you ever in your heart of\nhearts believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by her husband?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Good heavens! Haven't I always told you the man
is a villain? Haven't I always told you he would murder her in her bed?
Haven't I always hated him like poison?
subQuotationList: ['Good heavens!', "Haven't I always told you the man\nis a villain? Haven't I always told you he would murder her in her bed?\nHaven't I always hated him like poison?"]

quoteText:
Miss Howard, do you remember a conversation that took place on the day
of my friend's arrival here? He repeated it to me, and there is a
sentence of yours that has impressed me very much. Do you remember
affirming that if a crime had been committed, and anyone you loved had
been murdered, you felt certain that you would know by instinct who the
criminal was, even if you were quite unable to prove it?
subQuotationList:

of my friend's arrival here? He repeated it to me, and there is a

quoteText: Not at all.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all.']

And yet you will pay no attention to my instinct against Alfred

quoteText:
No, Because your instinct is not against Mr.
Inglethorp.

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText:
No. You wish to believe he committed the crime. You believe him
capable of committing it. But your instinct tells you he did not commit
it. It tells you more   shall I go on?
subQuotationList: ['No. You wish to believe he committed the crime. You believe him\ncapable of committing it. But your instinct tells you he did not commit\nit. It tells you more   shall I go on?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Shall I tell you why you have been so vehement against Mr. Inglethorp?
It is because you have been trying to believe what you wish to believe.
It is because you are trying to drown and stifle your instinct, which
tells you another name
subQuotationList:

No, no, no! Don't
say it! Oh, don't say it! It isn't true! It can't be true. I don't know

I will ask you nothing. It is enough for me that it is as I thought.

You will help me in spite of yourself. I ask you nothing   but you will

if it is only village gossip that
