Yard men in and out of the house like a jack-in-the-box! Never know
where they won't turn up next. Screaming headlines in every paper in
the country   damn all journalists, I say! Do you know there was a whole
crowd staring in at the lodge gates this morning. Sort of Madame
Tussaud's chamber of horrors business that can be seen for nothing.
Pretty thick, isn't it?"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Cheer up, John! It can't last for ever.
subQuotationList: ['Cheer up, John!', "It can't last for ever."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Can't it, though? It can last long enough for us never to be able to
hold up our heads again.
subQuotationList: ["Can't it, though? It can last long enough for us never to be able to\nhold up our heads again."]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText: No, no, you're getting morbid on the subject.
subQuotationList: ["No, no, you're getting morbid on the subject."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Enough to make a man morbid, to be stalked by beastly journalists and
stared at by gaping moon-faced idiots, wherever he goes! But there's
worse than that.
subQuotationList: ["Enough to make a man morbid, to be stalked by beastly journalists and\nstared at by gaping moon-faced idiots, wherever he goes! But there's\nworse than that."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Have you ever thought, Hastings   it's a nightmare to me   who did it? I
can't help feeling sometimes it must have been an accident.
Because   because   who could have done it? Now Inglethorp's out of the
way, there's no one else; no one, I mean, except   one of us.
subQuotationList:
["Have you ever thought, Hastings   it's a nightmare to me   who did it? I
can't help feeling sometimes it must have been an accident.
Because   because   who could have done it? Now Inglethorp's out of the
way, there's no one else; no one, I mean, except   one of us."]
speaker: John Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: No, John, it isn't one of us. How could it be?
subQuotationList: ['No, John,', "it isn't one of us. How could it be?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish']], [['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: I know, but, still, who else is there?
subQuotationList: ['I know, but, still, who else is there?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Can't you guess?
subQuotationList: ["Can't you guess?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No.
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Dr. Bauerstein!
subQuotationList: ['Dr. Bauerstein!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Impossible!
subQuotationList: ['Impossible!']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Not at all.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: But what earthly interest could he have in my mother's death?
subQuotationList: ["But what earthly interest could he have in my mother's death?"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
That I don't see, but I'll tell you this: Poirot thinks
so.
subQuotationList: ["That I don't see,", "but I'll tell you this: Poirot thinks\nso."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Poirot? Does he? How do you know?
subQuotationList: ['Poirot? Does he? How do you know?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
He said twice: And I've been thinking. You
know Inglethorp said he had put down the coffee in the hall? Well, it
was just then that Bauerstein arrived. Isn't it possible that, as
Inglethorp brought him through the hall, the doctor dropped something
into the coffee in passing?
subQuotationList:
['He said twice:', "And I've been thinking. You
know Inglethorp said he had put down the coffee in the hall? Well, it
was just then that Bauerstein arrived. Isn't it possible that, as
Inglethorp brought him through the hall, the doctor dropped something
into the coffee in passing?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
referringExpression: I told him of Poirots intense excitement on hearing that Dr Bauerstein had been at Styles on the fatal night and added
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot']], [['John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Bauerstein']]]

quoteText: H'm, It would have been very risky.
subQuotationList: ["H'm,", 'It would have been very risky.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: Yes, but it was possible.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but it was possible.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
And then, how could he know it was her coffee? No, old fellow, I don't
think that will wash.
subQuotationList: ["And then, how could he know it was her coffee? No, old fellow, I don't\nthink that will wash."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: You're quite right. That wasn't how it was done. Listen.
subQuotationList: ["You're quite right. That wasn't how it was done. Listen."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: But, look here, Bauerstein had had it analysed already?
subQuotationList: ['But, look here, Bauerstein had had it analysed already?']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Yes, yes, that's the point. I didn't see it either until now. Don't
you understand? Bauerstein had it analysed   that's just it! If
Bauerstein's the murderer, nothing could be simpler than for him to
substitute some ordinary cocoa for his sample, and send that to be
tested. And of course they would find no strychnine! But no one would
dream of suspecting Bauerstein, or think of taking another
sample   except Poirot,
subQuotationList:
["Yes, yes, that's the point. I didn't see it either until now. Don't
you understand? Bauerstein had it analysed   that's just it! If
Bauerstein's the murderer, nothing could be simpler than for him to
substitute some ordinary cocoa for his sample, and send that to be
tested. And of course they would find no strychnine! But no one would
dream of suspecting Bauerstein, or think of taking another
sample   except Poirot,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Dr. Bauerstein'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText: Yes, but what about the bitter taste that cocoa won't disguise?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, but what about the bitter taste that cocoa won't disguise?"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Well, we've only his word for that. And there are other possibilities.
He's admittedly one of the world's greatest toxicologists
subQuotationList: ["Well, we've only his word for that. And there are other possibilities.\nHe's admittedly one of the world's greatest toxicologists"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: One of the world's greatest what? Say it again.
subQuotationList: ["One of the world's greatest what? Say it again."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
He knows more about poisons than almost anybody, Well,
my idea is, that perhaps he's found some way of making strychnine
tasteless. Or it may not have been strychnine at all, but some obscure
drug no one has ever heard of, which produces much the same symptoms.
subQuotationList:
['He knows more about poisons than almost anybody,', "Well,
my idea is, that perhaps he's found some way of making strychnine
tasteless. Or it may not have been strychnine at all, but some obscure
drug no one has ever heard of, which produces much the same symptoms."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
H'm, yes, that might be, But look here, how could he have
got at the cocoa? That wasn't downstairs?
subQuotationList: ["H'm, yes, that might be,", "But look here, how could he have\ngot at the cocoa? That wasn't downstairs?"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: No, it wasn't,
subQuotationList: ["No, it wasn't,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
There's another thing, Something which makes me doubt if
what you say can be true.
subQuotationList: ["There's another thing,", 'Something which makes me doubt if\nwhat you say can be true.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: What's that?
subQuotationList: ["What's that?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Why, the fact that Bauerstein demanded a post-mortem. He needn't have
done so. Little Wilkins would have been quite content to let it go at
heart disease.
subQuotationList: ["Why, the fact that Bauerstein demanded a post-mortem. He needn't have\ndone so. Little Wilkins would have been quite content to let it go at\nheart disease."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Yes, But we don't know. Perhaps he thought it
safer in the long run. Someone might have talked afterwards. Then the
Home Office might have ordered exhumation. The whole thing would have
come out, then, and he would have been in an awkward position, for no
one would have believed that a man of his reputation could have been
deceived into calling it heart disease.
subQuotationList:
['Yes,', "But we don't know. Perhaps he thought it
safer in the long run. Someone might have talked afterwards. Then the
Home Office might have ordered exhumation. The whole thing would have
come out, then, and he would have been in an awkward position, for no
one would have believed that a man of his reputation could have been
deceived into calling it heart disease."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes, that's possible,
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's possible,"]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Still, I'm blest if
I can see what his motive could have been.
subQuotationList: ['Still,', "I'm blest if\nI can see what his motive could have been."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Look here, I may be altogether wrong. And, remember, all
this is in confidence.
subQuotationList: ['Look here,', 'I may be altogether wrong. And, remember, all\nthis is in confidence.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh, of course   that goes without saying.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, of course   that goes without saying.']
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
Of course! I'd love him to see it. He'd better come to tea there one
day. I must fix it up with him. He's such a dear little man! But he
_is_ funny. He made me take the brooch out of my tie the other day, and
put it in again, because he said it wasn't straight.
subQuotationList:
["Of course! I'd love him to see it. He'd better come to tea there one
day. I must fix it up with him. He's such a dear little man! But he
_is_ funny. He made me take the brooch out of my tie the other day, and
put it in again, because he said it wasn't straight."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

quoteText: It's quite a mania with him.
subQuotationList: ["It's quite a mania with him."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, isn't it?"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Mr. Hastings.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Hastings.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: After tea, I want to talk to you.
subQuotationList: ['After tea, I want to talk to you.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
Confound those detectives! I can't think what they're after! They've
been in every room in the house   turning things inside out, and upside
down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all
being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!
subQuotationList:
["Confound those detectives! I can't think what they're after! They've
been in every room in the house   turning things inside out, and upside
down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all
being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!"]
speaker: John Cavendish
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Lot of Paul Prys,
subQuotationList: ['Lot of Paul Prys,']
speaker: Evelyn Howard
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Mr. Hastings   you are always so kind, and you know such a lot.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Hastings   you are always so kind, and you know such a lot.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I want to ask your advice. What shall I do?
subQuotationList: ['I want to ask your advice. What shall I do?']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Do?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Yes. You see, Aunt Emily always told me I should be provided for. I
suppose she forgot, or didn't think she was likely to die   anyway, I am
_not_ provided for! And I don't know what to do. Do you think I ought
to go away from here at once?
subQuotationList:
["Yes. You see, Aunt Emily always told me I should be provided for. I
suppose she forgot, or didn't think she was likely to die   anyway, I am
_not_ provided for! And I don't know what to do. Do you think I ought
to go away from here at once?"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Good heavens, no! They don't want to part with you, I'm sure.
subQuotationList: ["Good heavens, no! They don't want to part with you, I'm sure."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Mrs. Cavendish does. She hates me.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Cavendish does. She hates me.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Hates you?
subQuotationList: ['Hates you?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes. I don't know why, but she can't bear me; and _he_ can't, either.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. I don't know why, but she can't bear me; and _he_ can't, either."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
There I know you're wrong, On the contrary, John is
very fond of you.
subQuotationList: ["There I know you're wrong,", 'On the contrary, John is\nvery fond of you.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, yes   _John_. I meant Lawrence. Not, of course, that I care whether
Lawrence hates me or not. Still, it's rather horrid when no one loves
you, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, yes   _John_. I meant Lawrence. Not, of course, that I care whether\nLawrence hates me or not. Still, it's rather horrid when no one loves\nyou, isn't it?"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
But they do, Cynthia dear, I'm sure you are
mistaken. Look, there is John   and Miss Howard
subQuotationList: ['But they do, Cynthia dear,', "I'm sure you are\nmistaken. Look, there is John   and Miss Howard"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Yes, John likes me, I think, and of
course Evie, for all her gruff ways, wouldn't be unkind to a fly. But
Lawrence never speaks to me if he can help it, and Mary can hardly
bring herself to be civil to me. She wants Evie to stay on, is begging
her to, but she doesn't want me, and   and   I don't know what to do.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, John likes me, I think, and of
course Evie, for all her gruff ways, wouldn't be unkind to a fly. But
Lawrence never speaks to me if he can help it, and Mary can hardly
bring herself to be civil to me. She wants Evie to stay on, is begging
her to, but she doesn't want me, and   and   I don't know what to do."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Evelyn Howard'], ['Mary Cavendish']]]

quoteText: Marry me, Cynthia.
subQuotationList: ['Marry me, Cynthia.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Don't be silly!
subQuotationList: ["Don't be silly!"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch
referringExpression: She sat up at once drew her hand away and said

quoteText:
I'm not being silly. I am asking you to do me the honour of becoming
my wife.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not being silly. I am asking you to do me the honour of becoming\nmy wife."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: funny dear.
subQuotationList: ['funny dear.']
speaker: Miss Murdoch
referringExpression: Cynthia burst out laughing and called me

quoteText:
It's perfectly sweet of you, but you know you don't want
to!
subQuotationList: ["It's perfectly sweet of you,", "but you know you don't want\nto!"]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Yes, I do. I've got
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I do. I've got"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Never mind what you've got. You don't really want to   and I don't
either.
subQuotationList: ["Never mind what you've got. You don't really want to   and I don't\neither."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText:
Well, of course, that settles it, But I don't see
anything to laugh at. There's nothing funny about a proposal.
subQuotationList: ['Well, of course, that settles it,', "But I don't see\nanything to laugh at. There's nothing funny about a proposal."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, indeed, Somebody might accept you next time.
Good-bye, you've cheered me up _very_ much.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed,', "Somebody might accept you next time.\nGood-bye, you've cheered me up _very_ much."]
speaker: Miss Murdoch

quoteText: Good afternoon, Is Dr. Bauerstein in?
subQuotationList: ['Good afternoon,', 'Is Dr. Bauerstein in?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Haven't you heard?
subQuotationList: ["Haven't you heard?"]
speaker: An Old Woman

quoteText: Heard what?
subQuotationList: ['Heard what?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: About him.
subQuotationList: ['About him.']
speaker: An Old Woman

quoteText: What about him?
subQuotationList: ['What about him?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: He's took.
subQuotationList: ["He's took."]
speaker: An Old Woman

quoteText: Took? Dead?
subQuotationList: ['Took? Dead?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No, took by the perlice.
subQuotationList: ['No, took by the perlice.']
speaker: An Old Woman

quoteText: By the police! Do you mean they've arrested him?
subQuotationList: ['By the police!', "Do you mean they've arrested him?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes, that's it, and
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's it, and"]
speaker: An Old Woman

quoteText:
Great Scott! You _were_ right, then. I couldn't believe it at the
time.
subQuotationList: ["Great Scott! You _were_ right, then. I couldn't believe it at the\ntime."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText:
No, it is astonishing until you get used to the idea, and see how it
makes everything fit in. Now, what are we to do? Of course, it will be
generally known to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['No, it is astonishing until you get used to the idea, and see how it\nmakes everything fit in. Now, what are we to do? Of course, it will be\ngenerally known to-morrow.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Never mind, we won't say anything at present. There
is no need. As you say, it will be known soon enough.
subQuotationList: ['Never mind,', "we won't say anything at present. There\nis no need. As you say, it will be known soon enough."]
speaker: John Cavendish

quoteText: _Bonjour, mon ami!_
subQuotationList: ['_Bonjour, mon ami!_']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Poirot, I was never so glad to see anyone. Listen,
I have said nothing to anybody but John. Is that right?
subQuotationList: ['Poirot,', 'I was never so glad to see anyone. Listen,\nI have said nothing to anybody but John. Is that right?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
My friend, I do not know what you are talking
about.
subQuotationList: ['My friend,', 'I do not know what you are talking\nabout.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Dr. Bauerstein's arrest, of course,
subQuotationList: ["Dr. Bauerstein's arrest, of course,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Is Bauerstein arrested, then?
subQuotationList: ['Is Bauerstein arrested, then?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Did you not know it?
subQuotationList: ['Did you not know it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Not the least in the world.
subQuotationList: ['Not the least in the world.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Still,
it does not surprise me. After all, we are only four miles from the
coast.
subQuotationList: ['Still,\nit does not surprise me. After all, we are only four miles from the\ncoast.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: The coast? What has that got to do with it?
subQuotationList: ['The coast?', 'What has that got to do with it?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Surely, it is obvious!
subQuotationList: ['Surely, it is obvious!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Not to me. No doubt I am very dense, but I cannot see what the
proximity of the coast has got to do with the murder of Mrs.
Inglethorp.
subQuotationList: ['Not to me. No doubt I am very dense, but I cannot see what the\nproximity of the coast has got to do with the murder of Mrs.\nInglethorp.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Nothing at all, of course, But we were
speaking of the arrest of Dr. Bauerstein.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing at all, of course,', 'But we were\nspeaking of the arrest of Dr. Bauerstein.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, he is arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp
subQuotationList: ['Well, he is arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
What? Dr.
Bauerstein arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp?
subQuotationList: ['What?', 'Dr.\nBauerstein arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Impossible! That would be too good a farce! Who told you that, my
friend?
subQuotationList: ['Impossible! That would be too good a farce! Who told you that, my\nfriend?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Well, no one exactly told me, But he is arrested.
subQuotationList: ['Well, no one exactly told me,', 'But he is arrested.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh, yes, very likely. But for espionage, _mon ami_.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, very likely. But for espionage, _mon ami_.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Espionage?
subQuotationList: ['Espionage?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Precisely.
subQuotationList: ['Precisely.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Not for poisoning Mrs. Inglethorp?
subQuotationList: ['Not for poisoning Mrs. Inglethorp?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Not unless our friend Japp has taken leave of his senses,
subQuotationList: ['Not unless our friend Japp has taken leave of his senses,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But   but I thought you thought so too?
subQuotationList: ['But   but I thought you thought so too?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Do you mean to say, that Dr. Bauerstein is a spy?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean to say,', 'that Dr. Bauerstein is a spy?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Have you never suspected it?
subQuotationList: ['Have you never suspected it?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: It never entered my head.
subQuotationList: ['It never entered my head.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
It did not strike you as peculiar that a famous London doctor should
bury himself in a little village like this, and should be in the habit
of walking about at all hours of the night, fully dressed?
subQuotationList: ['It did not strike you as peculiar that a famous London doctor should\nbury himself in a little village like this, and should be in the habit\nof walking about at all hours of the night, fully dressed?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, I never thought of such a thing.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I never thought of such a thing.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
He is, of course, a German by birth, though he has practised so long in this country that nobody thinks of
him as anything but an Englishman. He was naturalized about fifteen
years ago. A very clever man   a Jew, of course.
subQuotationList: ['He is, of course, a German by birth,', 'though he has practised so long in this country that nobody thinks of\nhim as anything but an Englishman. He was naturalized about fifteen\nyears ago. A very clever man   a Jew, of course.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: The blackguard!
subQuotationList: ['The blackguard!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Not at all. He is, on the contrary, a patriot. Think what he stands to
lose. I admire the man myself.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all. He is, on the contrary, a patriot. Think what he stands to\nlose. I admire the man myself.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
And this is the man with whom Mrs. Cavendish has been wandering about
all over the country!
subQuotationList: ['And this is the man with whom Mrs. Cavendish has been wandering about\nall over the country!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionTextsList: [['the man with whom Mrs. Cavendish has been wandering about', 'Mrs. Cavendish']]

quoteText:
Yes. I should fancy he had found her very useful, So long as gossip busied itself in coupling their names together, any
other vagaries of the doctor's passed unobserved.
subQuotationList: ['Yes. I should fancy he had found her very useful,', "So long as gossip busied itself in coupling their names together, any\nother vagaries of the doctor's passed unobserved."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Then you think he never really cared for her?
subQuotationList: ['Then you think he never really cared for her?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
That, of course, I cannot say, but   shall I tell you my own private
opinion, Hastings?
subQuotationList: ['That, of course, I cannot say, but   shall I tell you my own private\nopinion, Hastings?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Well, it is this: that Mrs. Cavendish does not care, and never has
cared one little jot about Dr. Bauerstein!
subQuotationList: ['Well, it is this: that Mrs. Cavendish does not care, and never has\ncared one little jot about Dr. Bauerstein!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Do you really think so?
subQuotationList: ['Do you really think so?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I am quite sure of it. And I will tell you why.
subQuotationList: ['I am quite sure of it. And I will tell you why.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Because she cares for someone else, _mon ami_.
subQuotationList: ['Because she cares for someone else, _mon ami_.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: On top of the wardrobe.
subQuotationList: ['On top of the wardrobe.']
speaker: Evelyn Howard

quoteText: Come here, Hastings. Now tell me, what is that initial   J. or L.?
subQuotationList: ['Come here, Hastings. Now tell me, what is that initial   J. or L.?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: It might be T., or it might be L., It certainly isn't a J.
subQuotationList: ['It might be T., or it might be L.,', "It certainly isn't a J."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Good, I, also, am of
your way of thinking. It is an L., depend upon it!
subQuotationList: ['Good,', 'I, also, am of\nyour way of thinking. It is an L., depend upon it!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Where did it come from? Is it important?
subQuotationList: ['Where did it come from?', 'Is it important?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Moderately so. It confirms a surmise of mine. Having deduced its
existence, I set Miss Howard to search for it, and, as you see, she has
been successful.
subQuotationList: ['Moderately so. It confirms a surmise of mine. Having deduced its\nexistence, I set Miss Howard to search for it, and, as you see, she has\nbeen successful.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: What did she mean by
subQuotationList: ['What did she mean by']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
She meant, that she found it on top of a
wardrobe.
subQuotationList: ['She meant,', 'that she found it on top of a\nwardrobe.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: A funny place for a piece of brown paper,
subQuotationList: ['A funny place for a piece of brown paper,']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Not at all. The top of a wardrobe is an excellent place for brown
paper and cardboard boxes. I have kept them there myself. Neatly
arranged, there is nothing to offend the eye.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all. The top of a wardrobe is an excellent place for brown\npaper and cardboard boxes. I have kept them there myself. Neatly\narranged, there is nothing to offend the eye.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Poirot, have you made up your mind about this
crime?
subQuotationList: ['Poirot,', 'have you made up your mind about this\ncrime?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes   that is to say, I believe I know how it was committed.
subQuotationList: ['Yes   that is to say, I believe I know how it was committed.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Unfortunately, I have no proof beyond my surmise, unless
subQuotationList: ['Unfortunately, I have no proof beyond my surmise, unless']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Mademoiselle Dorcas,
Mademoiselle Dorcas, _un moment, s'il vous pla  t!_
subQuotationList: ["Mademoiselle Dorcas,\nMademoiselle Dorcas, _un moment, s'il vous pla  t!_"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
referringExpression: he caught me by the arm and whirled me down the hall calling out

quoteText:
My good Dorcas, I have an idea   a little idea   if it should prove
justified, what magnificent chance! Tell me, on Monday, not Tuesday,
Dorcas, but Monday, the day before the tragedy, did anything go wrong
with Mrs. Inglethorp's bell?
subQuotationList:
["My good Dorcas, I have an idea   a little idea   if it should prove
justified, what magnificent chance! Tell me, on Monday, not Tuesday,
Dorcas, but Monday, the day before the tragedy, did anything go wrong
with Mrs. Inglethorp's bell?"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Yes, sir, now you mention it, it did; though I don't know how you came
to hear of it. A mouse, or some such, must have nibbled the wire
through. The man came and put it right on Tuesday morning.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, sir, now you mention it, it did; though I don't know how you came\nto hear of it. A mouse, or some such, must have nibbled the wire\nthrough. The man came and put it right on Tuesday morning."]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
See you, one should not ask for outside proof   no, reason should be
enough. But the flesh is weak, it is consolation to find that one is on
the right track. Ah, my friend, I am like a giant refreshed. I run! I
leap!
subQuotationList:
['See you, one should not ask for outside proof   no, reason should be
enough. But the flesh is weak, it is consolation to find that one is on
the right track. Ah, my friend, I am like a giant refreshed. I run! I
leap!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: What is your remarkable little friend doing? What is it all about?
subQuotationList: ['What is your remarkable little friend doing?', 'What is it all about?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Really, I can't tell you. He asked Dorcas some question about a bell,
and appeared so delighted with her answer that he is capering about as
you see!
subQuotationList: ["Really, I can't tell you. He asked Dorcas some question about a bell,\nand appeared so delighted with her answer that he is capering about as\nyou see!"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
How ridiculous! He's going out of the gate. Isn't he coming back
to-day?
subQuotationList: ["How ridiculous! He's going out of the gate. Isn't he coming back\nto-day?"]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: I don't know. I've given up trying to guess what he'll do next.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know. I've given up trying to guess what he'll do next."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Is he quite mad, Mr. Hastings?
subQuotationList: ['Is he quite mad, Mr. Hastings?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
I honestly don't know. Sometimes, I feel sure he is as mad as a
hatter; and then, just as he is at his maddest, I find there is method
in his madness.
subQuotationList: ["I honestly don't know. Sometimes, I feel sure he is as mad as a\nhatter; and then, just as he is at his maddest, I find there is method\nin his madness."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I see.
subQuotationList: ['I see.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
You are an excellent advocate, I have no doubt, Mr. Hastings, but in
this case your talents are quite thrown away. Cynthia will run no risk
of encountering any unkindness from me.
subQuotationList: ['You are an excellent advocate, I have no doubt, Mr. Hastings, but in\nthis case your talents are quite thrown away. Cynthia will run no risk\nof encountering any unkindness from me.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Mr. Hastings, do you think I and my husband are happy
together? Well, whether it is your business or not, I will
tell you that we are _not_ happy.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Hastings,', 'do you think I and my husband are happy\ntogether?', 'Well,', 'whether it is your business or not, I will\ntell you that we are _not_ happy.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings']], [['Mr. Hastings']], [], [['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
You don't know anything about me, do you? Where I come
from, who I was before I married John   anything, in fact? Well, I will
tell you. I will make a father confessor of you. You are kind, I
think   yes, I am sure you are kind.
subQuotationList:
["You don't know anything about me, do you?", 'Where I come
from, who I was before I married John   anything, in fact? Well, I will
tell you. I will make a father confessor of you. You are kind, I
think   yes, I am sure you are kind.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings']], [['John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText:
My father was English, but my mother was a
Russian.
subQuotationList: ['My father was English,', 'but my mother was a\nRussian.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Ah, now I understand
subQuotationList: ['Ah,', 'now I understand']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Understand what?
subQuotationList: ['Understand what?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
A hint of something foreign   different   that there has always been about
you.
subQuotationList: ['A hint of something foreign   different   that there has always been about\nyou.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
My mother was very beautiful, I believe. I don't know, because I never
saw her. She died when I was quite a little child. I believe there was
some tragedy connected with her death   she took an overdose of some
sleeping draught by mistake. However that may be, my father was
broken-hearted. Shortly afterwards, he went into the Consular Service.
Everywhere he went, I went with him. When I was twenty-three, I had
been nearly all over the world. It was a splendid life   I loved it.
subQuotationList:
["My mother was very beautiful, I believe. I don't know, because I never
saw her. She died when I was quite a little child. I believe there was
some tragedy connected with her death   she took an overdose of some
sleeping draught by mistake. However that may be, my father was
broken-hearted. Shortly afterwards, he went into the Consular Service.
Everywhere he went, I went with him. When I was twenty-three, I had
been nearly all over the world. It was a splendid life   I loved it."]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Then my father died. He left me very badly off. I had to go and live
with some old aunts in Yorkshire.
subQuotationList: ['Then my father died. He left me very badly off. I had to go and live\nwith some old aunts in Yorkshire.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
You will understand
me when I say that it was a deadly life for a girl brought up as I had
been. The narrowness, the deadly monotony of it, almost drove me mad.
subQuotationList: ['You will understand\nme when I say that it was a deadly life for a girl brought up as I had\nbeen. The narrowness, the deadly monotony of it, almost drove me mad.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
And then I met
John Cavendish.
subQuotationList: ['And then I met\nJohn Cavendish.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
referringExpression: She paused a minute and added

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
You can imagine that, from my aunts' point of view, it was a very good
match for me. But I can honestly say it was not this fact which weighed
with me. No, he was simply a way of escape from the insufferable
monotony of my life.
subQuotationList:
["You can imagine that, from my aunts' point of view, it was a very good
match for me. But I can honestly say it was not this fact which weighed
with me. No, he was simply a way of escape from the insufferable
monotony of my life."]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Don't misunderstand me. I was quite honest with him. I told him, what
was true, that I liked him very much, that I hoped to come to like him
more, but that I was not in any way what the world calls    in love' with
him. He declared that that satisfied him, and so   we were married.
subQuotationList:
["Don't misunderstand me. I was quite honest with him. I told him, what
was true, that I liked him very much, that I hoped to come to like him
more, but that I was not in any way what the world calls    in love' with
him. He declared that that satisfied him, and so   we were married."]
speaker: Mary Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
I think   I am sure   he cared for me at first. But I suppose we were not
well matched. Almost at once, we drifted apart. He   it is not a pleasing
thing for my pride, but it is the truth   tired of me very soon.
subQuotationList: ['I think   I am sure   he cared for me at first. But I suppose we were not\nwell matched. Almost at once, we drifted apart. He   it is not a pleasing\nthing for my pride, but it is the truth   tired of me very soon.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
Oh, yes, he
did! Not that it matters now   now that we've come to the parting of the
ways.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, yes, he\ndid! Not that it matters now   now that we've come to the parting of the\nways."]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I mean that I am not going to remain at Styles.
subQuotationList: ['I mean that I am not going to remain at Styles.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: You and John are not going to live here?
subQuotationList: ['You and John are not going to live here?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: John may live here, but I shall not.
subQuotationList: ['John may live here, but I shall not.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: You are going to leave him?
subQuotationList: ['You are going to leave him?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: But why?
subQuotationList: ['But why?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Perhaps   because I want to be   free!
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps   because I want to be   free!']
speaker: Mary Cavendish
referringExpression: She paused a long time and said

quoteText:
You don't know, you don't know, how this hateful place has been prison
to me!
subQuotationList: ["You don't know, you don't know, how this hateful place has been prison\nto me!"]
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: I understand, but   but don't do anything rash.
subQuotationList: ['I understand,', "but   but don't do anything rash."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Oh, rash!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, rash!']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: You know that Dr. Bauerstein has been arrested?
subQuotationList: ['You know that Dr. Bauerstein has been arrested?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: John was so kind as to break that to me this morning.
subQuotationList: ['John was so kind as to break that to me this morning.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Well, what do you think?
subQuotationList: ['Well, what do you think?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Of what?
subQuotationList: ['Of what?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Of the arrest?
subQuotationList: ['Of the arrest?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
What should I think? Apparently he is a German spy; so the gardener
had told John.
subQuotationList: ['What should I think? Apparently he is a German spy; so the gardener\nhad told John.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
These are quite dead. I must do them again. Would you mind
moving   thank you, Mr. Hastings.
subQuotationList: ['These are quite dead. I must do them again. Would you mind\nmoving   thank you, Mr. Hastings.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Gone to London again?
subQuotationList: ['Gone to London again?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Silly ass! I told him Wednesday was the one day she
wasn't there! Well, tell him to look us up to-morrow morning, will
you?
subQuotationList: ['Silly ass!', "I told him Wednesday was the one day she\nwasn't there! Well, tell him to look us up to-morrow morning, will\nyou?"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot']], [['Hercule Poirot'], ['Miss Murdoch'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: No, I don't think I shall. He can come up here if he wants to see us.
subQuotationList: ["No, I don't think I shall. He can come up here if he wants to see us."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: Oh!
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish

quoteText: What is it? I could go if there's anything special.
subQuotationList: ['What is it?', "I could go if there's anything special."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: It's nothing much, but   well, if you are going, will you tell him
subQuotationList: ["It's nothing much, but   well, if you are going, will you tell him"]
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish

quoteText:
I think I've found the extra
coffee-cup!
subQuotationList: ["I think I've found the extra\ncoffee-cup!"]
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish

quoteText: What is it? You are not ill, I trust?
subQuotationList: ['What is it?', 'You are not ill, I trust?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No, no, not ill. But I decide an affair of great moment.
subQuotationList: ['No, no, not ill. But I decide an affair of great moment.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Whether to catch the criminal or not?
subQuotationList: ['Whether to catch the criminal or not?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: To speak or not to speak,' as your so great Shakespeare says,
subQuotationList: ["To speak or not to speak,' as your so great Shakespeare says,"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: You are not serious, Poirot?
subQuotationList: ['You are not serious, Poirot?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I am of the most serious. For the most serious of all things hangs in
the balance.
subQuotationList: ['I am of the most serious. For the most serious of all things hangs in\nthe balance.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: And that is?
subQuotationList: ['And that is?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: A woman's happiness, _mon ami_,
subQuotationList: ["A woman's happiness, _mon ami_,"]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
The moment has come, and I do not know
what to do. For, see you, it is a big stake for which I play. No one
but I, Hercule Poirot, would attempt it!
subQuotationList: ['The moment has come,', 'and I do not know\nwhat to do. For, see you, it is a big stake for which I play. No one\nbut I, Hercule Poirot, would attempt it!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Aha! So he has found the extra coffee-cup. That is good.
He has more intelligence than would appear, this long-faced Monsieur
Lawrence of yours!
subQuotationList: ['Aha!', 'So he has found the extra coffee-cup. That is good.\nHe has more intelligence than would appear, this long-faced Monsieur\nLawrence of yours!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
It is true. I have the head of a sieve. However, the other young lady
was most kind. She was sorry for my disappointment, and showed me
everything in the kindest way.
subQuotationList: ['It is true. I have the head of a sieve. However, the other young lady\nwas most kind. She was sorry for my disappointment, and showed me\neverything in the kindest way.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Oh, well, that's all right, then, and you must go to tea with Cynthia
another day.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, well, that's all right, then, and you must go to tea with Cynthia\nanother day."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I am sorry for that, I always had hopes of that letter. But
no, it was not to be. This affair must all be unravelled from within. These little grey cells. It is as
you say over here.
subQuotationList: ['I am sorry for that,', 'I always had hopes of that letter. But\nno, it was not to be. This affair must all be unravelled from within.', 'These little grey cells. It is', 'as\nyou say over here.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Are you a judge of
finger-marks, my friend?
subQuotationList: ['Are you a judge of\nfinger-marks, my friend?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
No, I know that there are no two
finger-marks alike, but that's as far as my science goes.
subQuotationList: ['No,', "I know that there are no two\nfinger-marks alike, but that's as far as my science goes."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Exactly.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I have numbered them, 1, 2, 3. Will you describe them to me?
subQuotationList: ['I have numbered them, 1, 2, 3. Will you describe them to me?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
All greatly magnified, I see. No. 1, I should say, are a man's
finger-prints; thumb and first finger. No. 2 are a lady's; they are
much smaller, and quite different in every way. No. 3
subQuotationList: ["All greatly magnified, I see. No. 1, I should say, are a man's\nfinger-prints; thumb and first finger. No. 2 are a lady's; they are\nmuch smaller, and quite different in every way. No. 3"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
there seem to be a lot of confused finger-marks, but here,
very distinctly, are No. 1's.
subQuotationList: ["there seem to be a lot of confused finger-marks, but here,\nvery distinctly, are No. 1's."]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Overlapping the others?
subQuotationList: ['Overlapping the others?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: You recognize them beyond fail?
subQuotationList: ['You recognize them beyond fail?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, yes; they are identical.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes; they are identical.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I suppose, that as usual, you are not going to explain?
subQuotationList: ['I suppose,', 'that as usual, you are not going to explain?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
On the contrary. No. 1 were the finger-prints of Monsieur Lawrence.
No. 2 were those of Mademoiselle Cynthia. They are not important. I
merely obtained them for comparison. No. 3 is a little more
complicated.
subQuotationList:
['On the contrary. No. 1 were the finger-prints of Monsieur Lawrence.
No. 2 were those of Mademoiselle Cynthia. They are not important. I
merely obtained them for comparison. No. 3 is a little more
complicated.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
It is, as you see, highly magnified. You may have noticed a sort of
blur extending all across the picture. I will not describe to you the
special apparatus, dusting powder, etc., which I used. It is a
well-known process to the police, and by means of it you can obtain a
photograph of the finger-prints of any object in a very short space of
time. Well, my friend, you have seen the finger-marks   it remains to
tell you the particular object on which they had been left.
subQuotationList:
['It is, as you see, highly magnified. You may have noticed a sort of
blur extending all across the picture. I will not describe to you the
special apparatus, dusting powder, etc., which I used. It is a
well-known process to the police, and by means of it you can obtain a
photograph of the finger-prints of any object in a very short space of
time. Well, my friend, you have seen the finger-marks   it remains to
tell you the particular object on which they had been left.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: Go on   I am really excited.
subQuotationList: ['Go on   I am really excited.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
_Eh bien!_ Photo No. 3 represents the highly magnified surface of a
tiny bottle in the top poison cupboard of the dispensary in the Red
Cross Hospital at Tadminster   which sounds like the house that Jack
built!
subQuotationList:
['_Eh bien!_ Photo No. 3 represents the highly magnified surface of a
tiny bottle in the top poison cupboard of the dispensary in the Red
Cross Hospital at Tadminster   which sounds like the house that Jack
built!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Good heavens! But what were Lawrence Cavendish's
finger-marks doing on it? He never went near the poison cupboard the
day we were there!
subQuotationList: ['Good heavens!', "But what were Lawrence Cavendish's\nfinger-marks doing on it? He never went near the poison cupboard the\nday we were there!"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']]]

quoteText: Oh, yes, he did!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, he did!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Impossible! We were all together the whole time.
subQuotationList: ['Impossible! We were all together the whole time.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, my friend, there was a moment when you were not all together.
There was a moment when you could not have been all together, or it
would not have been necessary to call to Monsieur Lawrence to come and
join you on the balcony.
subQuotationList:
['No, my friend, there was a moment when you were not all together.
There was a moment when you could not have been all together, or it
would not have been necessary to call to Monsieur Lawrence to come and
join you on the balcony.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Hastings'], ['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: I'd forgotten that, But it was only for a moment.
subQuotationList: ["I'd forgotten that,", 'But it was only for a moment.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Long enough.
subQuotationList: ['Long enough.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Long enough for what?
subQuotationList: ['Long enough for what?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Long enough for a gentleman who had once studied medicine to gratify a
very natural interest and curiosity.
subQuotationList: ['Long enough for a gentleman who had once studied medicine to gratify a\nvery natural interest and curiosity.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionTextsList: [['a gentleman who had once studied medicine']]

quoteText: Poirot, what was in this particular little bottle?
subQuotationList: ['Poirot,', 'what was in this particular little bottle?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Hydro-chloride of strychnine,
subQuotationList: ['Hydro-chloride of strychnine,']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Good heavens!
subQuotationList: ['Good heavens!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
They use the pure hydro-chloride of strychnine very little   only
occasionally for pills. It is the official solution, Liq. Strychnine
Hydro-clor. that is used in most medicines. That is why the
finger-marks have remained undisturbed since then.
subQuotationList:
['They use the pure hydro-chloride of strychnine very little   only
occasionally for pills. It is the official solution, Liq. Strychnine
Hydro-clor. that is used in most medicines. That is why the

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: How did you manage to take this photograph?
subQuotationList: ['How did you manage to take this photograph?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I dropped my hat from the balcony, Visitors
were not permitted below at that hour, so, in spite of my many
apologies, Mademoiselle Cynthia's colleague had to go down and fetch it
for me.
subQuotationList:
['I dropped my hat from the balcony,', "Visitors
were not permitted below at that hour, so, in spite of my many
apologies, Mademoiselle Cynthia's colleague had to go down and fetch it
for me."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Then you knew what you were going to find?
subQuotationList: ['Then you knew what you were going to find?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No, not at all. I merely realized that it was possible, from your
story, for Monsieur Lawrence to go to the poison cupboard. The
possibility had to be confirmed, or eliminated.
subQuotationList: ['No, not at all. I merely realized that it was possible, from your\nstory, for Monsieur Lawrence to go to the poison cupboard. The\npossibility had to be confirmed, or eliminated.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
Poirot, your gaiety does not deceive me. This is a very
important discovery.
subQuotationList: ['Poirot,', 'your gaiety does not deceive me. This is a very\nimportant discovery.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I do not know, But one thing does strike me. No doubt
it has struck you too.
subQuotationList: ['I do not know,', 'But one thing does strike me. No doubt\nit has struck you too.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: What is that?
subQuotationList: ['What is that?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Why, that there is altogether too much strychnine about this case.
This is the third time we run up against it. There was strychnine in
Mrs. Inglethorp's tonic. There is the strychnine sold across the
counter at Styles St. Mary by Mace. Now we have more strychnine,
handled by one of the household. It is confusing; and, as you know, I
do not like confusion.
subQuotationList:
["Why, that there is altogether too much strychnine about this case.
This is the third time we run up against it. There was strychnine in
Mrs. Inglethorp's tonic. There is the strychnine sold across the
counter at Styles St. Mary by Mace. Now we have more strychnine,
handled by one of the household. It is confusing; and, as you know, I
do not like confusion."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Mace'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

quoteText: There is a lady below, asking for Mr Hastings.
subQuotationList: ['There is a lady below, asking for Mr Hastings.']
speaker: One Of The Other Belgians

quoteText: A lady?
subQuotationList: ['A lady?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I have been visiting an old woman in the village, and
as Lawrence told me you were with Monsieur Poirot I thought I would
call for you.
subQuotationList: ['I have been visiting an old woman in the village,', 'and\nas Lawrence told me you were with Monsieur Poirot I thought I would\ncall for you.']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText:
Alas, madame, I thought you had come to honour me with
a visit!
subQuotationList: ['Alas, madame,', 'I thought you had come to honour me with\na visit!']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I will some day, if you ask me,
subQuotationList: ['I will some day, if you ask me,']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: That is well. If you should need a father confessor, madame
subQuotationList: ['That is well. If you should need a father confessor, madame']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
remember, Papa Poirot is always at your
service.
subQuotationList: ['remember, Papa Poirot is always at your\nservice.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Come, will you not walk back with us too, Monsieur Poirot?
subQuotationList: ['Come, will you not walk back with us too, Monsieur Poirot?']
speaker: Mary Cavendish

quoteText: Enchanted, madame.
subQuotationList: ['Enchanted, madame.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Oh, m'am! Oh, m'am! I don't know how to tell you
subQuotationList: ["Oh, m'am! Oh, m'am! I don't know how to tell you"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: What is it, Dorcas? Tell us at once.
subQuotationList: ['What is it, Dorcas?', 'Tell us at once.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
It's those wicked detectives. They've arrested him   they've arrested
Mr. Cavendish!
subQuotationList: ["It's those wicked detectives. They've arrested him   they've arrested\nMr. Cavendish!"]
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText: Arrested Lawrence?
subQuotationList: ['Arrested Lawrence?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: No, sir. Not Mr. Lawrence   Mr. John.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir. Not Mr. Lawrence   Mr. John.']
speaker: Dorcas

quoteText:
Yes, she is of those women who show at their best in adversity. It
brings out all that is sweetest and truest in them. Her pride and her
jealousy have
subQuotationList: ['Yes, she is of those women who show at their best in adversity. It\nbrings out all that is sweetest and truest in them. Her pride and her\njealousy have']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Jealousy?
subQuotationList: ['Jealousy?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Yes. Have you not realized that she is an unusually jealous woman? As
I was saying, her pride and jealousy have been laid aside. She thinks
of nothing but her husband, and the terrible fate that is hanging over
him.
subQuotationList:
['Yes. Have you not realized that she is an unusually jealous woman? As
I was saying, her pride and jealousy have been laid aside. She thinks
of nothing but her husband, and the terrible fate that is hanging over
him.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
Even now, I can hardly believe it. You see, up to the very
last minute, I thought it was Lawrence!
subQuotationList: ['Even now,', 'I can hardly believe it. You see, up to the very\nlast minute, I thought it was Lawrence!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: I know you did.
subQuotationList: ['I know you did.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But John! My old friend John!
subQuotationList: ['But John! My old friend John!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Every murderer is probably somebody's old friend, You cannot mix up sentiment and reason.
subQuotationList: ["Every murderer is probably somebody's old friend,", 'You cannot mix up sentiment and reason.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I must say I think you might have given me a hint.
subQuotationList: ['I must say I think you might have given me a hint.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Perhaps, _mon ami_, I did not do so, just because he _was_ your old
friend.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps, _mon ami_, I did not do so, just because he _was_ your old\nfriend.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: But, Poirot
subQuotationList: ['But, Poirot']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Oh, my friend, have I not said to you all along that I have no proofs.
It is one thing to know that a man is guilty, it is quite another
matter to prove him so. And, in this case, there is terribly little
evidence. That is the whole trouble. I, Hercule Poirot, know, but I
lack the last link in my chain. And unless I can find that missing
link
subQuotationList:
['Oh, my friend, have I not said to you all along that I have no proofs.
It is one thing to know that a man is guilty, it is quite another
matter to prove him so. And, in this case, there is terribly little
evidence. That is the whole trouble. I, Hercule Poirot, know, but I
lack the last link in my chain. And unless I can find that missing
link']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: When did you first suspect John Cavendish?
subQuotationList: ['When did you first suspect John Cavendish?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Did you not suspect him at all?
subQuotationList: ['Did you not suspect him at all?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No, indeed.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed.']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Not after that fragment of conversation you overheard between Mrs.
Cavendish and her mother-in-law, and her subsequent lack of frankness
at the inquest?
subQuotationList: ['Not after that fragment of conversation you overheard between Mrs.\nCavendish and her mother-in-law, and her subsequent lack of frankness\nat the inquest?']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: No.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Did you not put two and two together, and reflect that if it was not
Alfred Inglethorp who was quarrelling with his wife   and you remember,
he strenuously denied it at the inquest   it must be either Lawrence or
John. Now, if it was Lawrence, Mary Cavendish's conduct was just as
inexplicable. But if, on the other hand, it was John, the whole thing
was explained quite naturally.
subQuotationList:
["Did you not put two and two together, and reflect that if it was not
Alfred Inglethorp who was quarrelling with his wife   and you remember,
he strenuously denied it at the inquest   it must be either Lawrence or
John. Now, if it was Lawrence, Mary Cavendish's conduct was just as
inexplicable. But if, on the other hand, it was John, the whole thing
was explained quite naturally."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish']]]

quoteText:
So, it was John who quarrelled
with his mother that afternoon?
subQuotationList: ['So,', 'it was John who quarrelled\nwith his mother that afternoon?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText: Exactly.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: And you have known this all along?
subQuotationList: ['And you have known this all along?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Certainly. Mrs. Cavendish's behaviour could only be explained that
way.
subQuotationList: ["Certainly. Mrs. Cavendish's behaviour could only be explained that\nway."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: And yet you say he may be acquitted?
subQuotationList: ['And yet you say he may be acquitted?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Certainly I do. At the police court proceedings, we shall hear the
case for the prosecution, but in all probability his solicitors will
advise him to reserve his defence. That will be sprung upon us at the
trial. And   ah, by the way, I have a word of caution to give you, my
friend. I must not appear in the case.
subQuotationList:
['Certainly I do. At the police court proceedings, we shall hear the
case for the prosecution, but in all probability his solicitors will
advise him to reserve his defence. That will be sprung upon us at the
trial. And   ah, by the way, I have a word of caution to give you, my
friend. I must not appear in the case.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Hercule Poirot', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Hastings']]]

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
No. Officially, I have nothing to do with it. Until I have found that
last link in my chain, I must remain behind the scenes. Mrs. Cavendish
must think I am working for her husband, not against him.
subQuotationList: ['No. Officially, I have nothing to do with it. Until I have found that\nlast link in my chain, I must remain behind the scenes. Mrs. Cavendish\nmust think I am working for her husband, not against him.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: I say, that's playing it a bit low down,
subQuotationList: ["I say, that's playing it a bit low down,"]
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
Not at all. We have to deal with a most clever and unscrupulous man,
and we must use any means in our power   otherwise he will slip through
our fingers. That is why I have been careful to remain in the
background. All the discoveries have been made by Japp, and Japp will
take all the credit. If I am called upon to give evidence at all
subQuotationList:
['Not at all. We have to deal with a most clever and unscrupulous man,

It is quite _en r  gle_, Strangely enough, I can
give evidence that will demolish one contention of the prosecution.

The one that relates to the destruction of the will. John Cavendish
did not destroy that will.

quoteText:
That hateful man! What a net he has drawn around my poor John! How he
twisted every little fact until he made it seem what it wasn't!

quoteText:
Yes, Mr.
Hastings, you do not think   surely it could not have been Lawrence   Oh,
no, that could not be!

quoteText:
Ah! He is a clever man, that Sir
Ernest.
subQuotationList: ['Ah!', 'He is a clever man, that Sir\nErnest.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText: Do you think he believes Lawrence guilty?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think he believes Lawrence guilty?']
speaker: Mr. Hastings

quoteText:
I do not think he believes or cares anything! No, what he is trying
for is to create such confusion in the minds of the jury that they are
divided in their opinion as to which brother did it. He is endeavouring
to make out that there is quite as much evidence against Lawrence as
against John   and I am not at all sure that he will not succeed.
subQuotationList:
['I do not think he believes or cares anything! No, what he is trying
for is to create such confusion in the minds of the jury that they are
divided in their opinion as to which brother did it. He is endeavouring
to make out that there is quite as much evidence against Lawrence as
against John   and I am not at all sure that he will not succeed.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ernest Heavywether'], ['Ernest Heavywether'], ['Ernest Heavywether'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Ernest Heavywether']]]

quoteText:
Acting on information received, Superintendent Summerhaye and myself
searched the prisoner's room, during his temporary absence from the
house. In his chest of drawers, hidden beneath some underclothing, we
found: first, a pair of gold-rimmed pince-nez similar to those worn by
Mr. Inglethorp secondly, this phial.
subQuotationList:
["Acting on information received, Superintendent Summerhaye and myself
searched the prisoner's room, during his temporary absence from the
house. In his chest of drawers, hidden beneath some underclothing, we
found: first, a pair of gold-rimmed pince-nez similar to those worn by
Mr. Inglethorp", 'secondly, this phial.']

to find?

speaker: Hercule Poirot

quoteText:
_Messieurs, mesdames_, as you all know, I was called in by Monsieur
John Cavendish to investigate this case. I at once examined the bedroom
of the deceased which, by the advice of the doctors, had been kept
locked, and was consequently exactly as it had been when the tragedy
occurred. I found: first, a fragment of green material; second, a stain
on the carpet near the window, still damp; thirdly, an empty box of
bromide powders.
subQuotationList:
['_Messieurs, mesdames_, as you all know, I was called in by Monsieur
John Cavendish to investigate this case. I at once examined the bedroom
of the deceased which, by the advice of the doctors, had been kept
locked, and was consequently exactly as it had been when the tragedy
occurred. I found: first, a fragment of green material; second, a stain
on the carpet near the window, still damp; thirdly, an empty box of
bromide powders.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Annie']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Inglethorp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Japp', 'Summerhaye', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Annie'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Annie'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Dr. Bauerstein', 'Dr. Wilkins']]]

quoteText:
To take the fragment of green material first, I found it caught in the
bolt of the communicating door between that room and the adjoining one
occupied by Mademoiselle Cynthia. I handed the fragment over to the
police who did not consider it of much importance. Nor did they
recognize it for what it was   a piece torn from a green land armlet.
subQuotationList:
['To take the fragment of green material first, I found it caught in the
bolt of the communicating door between that room and the adjoining one
occupied by Mademoiselle Cynthia. I handed the fragment over to the
police who did not consider it of much importance. Nor did they
recognize it for what it was   a piece torn from a green land armlet.']
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Annie']

quoteText:
Now there was only one person at Styles who worked on the land   Mrs.
Cavendish. Therefore it must have been Mrs. Cavendish who entered the
deceased's room through the door communicating with Mademoiselle
Cynthia's room.
subQuotationList:
["Now there was only one person at Styles who worked on the land   Mrs.
Cavendish. Therefore it must have been Mrs. Cavendish who entered the
deceased's room through the door communicating with Mademoiselle
Cynthia's room."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Annie']

quoteText: But that door was bolted on the inside!
subQuotationList: ['But that door was bolted on the inside!']
speaker: Mr. Hastings
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Hercule Poirot', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Japp', 'Summerhaye', 'Annie']

quoteText:
When I examined the room, yes. But in the first place we have only her
word for it, since it was she who tried that particular door and
reported it fastened. In the ensuing confusion she would have had ample
opportunity to shoot the bolt across. I took an early opportunity of
verifying my conjectures. To begin with, the fragment corresponds
exactly with a tear in Mrs. Cavendish's armlet. Also, at the inquest,
Mrs. Cavendish declared that she had heard, from her own room, the fall
of the table by the bed. I took an early opportunity of testing that
statement by stationing my friend Monsieur Hastings in the left wing of
the building, just outside Mrs. Cavendish's door. I myself, in company
with the police, went to the deceased's room, and whilst there I,
apparently accidentally, knocked over the table in question, but found
that, as I had expected, Monsieur Hastings had heard no sound at all.
This confirmed my belief that Mrs. Cavendish was not speaking the truth
when she declared that she had been dressing in her room at the time of
the tragedy. In fact, I was convinced that, far from having been in her
own room, Mrs. Cavendish was actually in the deceased's room when the
alarm was given.
subQuotationList:
["When I examined the room, yes. But in the first place we have only her
word for it, since it was she who tried that particular door and
reported it fastened. In the ensuing confusion she would have had ample
opportunity to shoot the bolt across. I took an early opportunity of
verifying my conjectures. To begin with, the fragment corresponds
exactly with a tear in Mrs. Cavendish's armlet. Also, at the inquest,
Mrs. Cavendish declared that she had heard, from her own room, the fall
of the table by the bed. I took an early opportunity of testing that
statement by stationing my friend Monsieur Hastings in the left wing of
the building, just outside Mrs. Cavendish's door. I myself, in company
with the police, went to the deceased's room, and whilst there I,
apparently accidentally, knocked over the table in question, but found
that, as I had expected, Monsieur Hastings had heard no sound at all.
This confirmed my belief that Mrs. Cavendish was not speaking the truth
when she declared that she had been dressing in her room at the time of
the tragedy. In fact, I was convinced that, far from having been in her
own room, Mrs. Cavendish was actually in the deceased's room when the
alarm was given."]
speaker: Hercule Poirot
addressees: ['Mary Cavendish', 'Dorcas', 'Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Inglethorp', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Evelyn Howard', 'Japp', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish', 'Summerhaye', 'Annie']
mentionTextsList: [['her', 'she', 'Mrs. Cavendish', 'Mrs. Cavendish', 'she', 'her', 'my friend Monsieur Hastings', 'Mrs. Cavendish', 'Monsieur Hastings', 'Mrs. Cavendish', 'she', 'she', 'her', 'her', 'Mrs. Cavendish', 'the deceased']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mary Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

quoteText:
I proceeded to reason on that assumption. Mrs. Cavendish is in her
mother-in-law's room. We will say that she is seeking for something and
has not yet found it. Suddenly Mrs. Inglethorp awakens and is seized
with an alarming paroxysm. She flings out her arm, overturning the bed
table, and then pulls desperately at the bell. Mrs. Cavendish,
startled, drops her candle, scattering the grease on the carpet. She
picks it up, and retreats quickly to Mademoiselle Cynthia's room,
closing the door behind her. She hurries out into the passage, for the
servants must not find her where she is. But it is too late! Already
footsteps are echoing along the gallery which connects the two wings.
What can she do? Quick as thought, she hurries back to the young girl's
room, and starts shaking her awake. The hastily aroused household come
trooping down the passage. They are all busily battering at Mrs.
Inglethorp's door. It occurs to nobody that Mrs. Cavendish has not
arrived with the rest, but   and this is significant   I can find no one
who saw her come from the other wing.
subQuotationList:
["I proceeded to reason on that assumption. Mrs. Cavendish is in her
mother-in-law's room. We will say that she is seeking for something and
has not yet found it. Suddenly Mrs. Inglethorp awakens and is seized
with an alarming paroxysm. She flings out her arm, overturning the bed
table, and then pulls desperately at the bell. Mrs. Cavendish,
startled, drops her candle, scattering the grease on the carpet. She
picks it up, and retreats quickly to Mademoiselle Cynthia's room,
closing the door behind her. She hurries out into the passage, for the
servants must not find her where she is. But it is too late! Already
footsteps are echoing along the gallery which connects the two wings.
What can she do? Quick as thought, she hurries back to the young girl's
room, and starts shaking her awake. The hastily aroused household come
trooping down the passage. They are all busily battering at Mrs.
Inglethorp's door. It occurs to nobody that Mrs. Cavendish has not
arrived with the rest, but   and this is significant   I can find no one
who saw her come from the other wing."]
